editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

note.p: Moll Cut-Purse was the alias of Mary Frith.
The first leaf and the last leaf are blank.
For stop-press variants see "Studies in bibliography" 37, p. 159-70.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

keywords.term: Cutpurse, Moll, -- 1584?-1659 -- Drama -- Early works to 1800.
Brigands and robbers -- Drama -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: The roaring girl. Or Moll cutpurse.
As it hath lately been acted on the fortune-stage by the prince his players.
Written by T. Middleton and T. Dekkar.

figure.p: My case is altered, I must work for my living.

div.p: Printed at London for Thomas archer, and are to be sold at his shop in Pope's head-palace, near the royal exchange. 1611.

div.head: To the comic, play-readers, venery, and laughter.
div.p:
The fashion of playmaking, I can properly compare to nothing, so naturally, as the alteration in apparel: for in the time of the great-crop-doublet, your huge bombasted plays, quilted with mighty words to lean purpose was only then in fashion. And as the doublet fell, neater inventions began to set up. Now in the time of spruceness, our plays follow the niceness of our garments, single plots, quaint conceits, lecherous jests, dressed up in hanging sleeves, and those are fit for the times, and the termers: such a kind of light-colour summer stuff, mingled with divers colours, you shall find this published comedy, good to keep you in an afternoon from dice, at home in your chambers; and for venery you shall find enough, for sixpence, but well couched and you mark it. For Venus being a woman passes through the play in doublet and breeches, a brave disguise and a safe one, if the statute untie not her codpiece point. The book I make no question, but is fit for many of your companies, as well as the person itself, and may be allowed both gallery room at the playhouse, and chamber-room at your lodging: worse things I must needs confess the world
has taxed her for, then has been written of her; but 'tis the excellency of a writer, to leave things better than he finds 'em; though some obscene fellow (That cares not what he writes against others, yet keeps a mystical bawdy-house himself, and entertains drunkards, to make use of their pockets, and vent his private bottle-ale at midnight) though such a one would have ripped up the most nasty vice, that ever hell belched forth, and presented it to a modest assembly; yet we rather wish in such discoveries, where reputation lies bleeding, a slackness of truth, than fullness of slander.

lg.l: A play (Expected long) makes the audience look
For wonders: — that each scene should be a book,
Composed to all perfection; each one comes
And brings a play in's head with him: up he sums,
What he would of a roaring girl have writ;
If that he finds not here, he mews at it.
Only we entreat you think our scene.
Cannot speak high (The subject being but mean)
A roaring girl (Whose notes till now never were)
Shall fill with laughter our vast theater,
That's all which I dare promise: tragic passion,
And such grave stuff, is this day out of fashion.
I see attention sets wide open her gates
Of hearing, and with covetous listening waits,
To know what girl, this roaring girl should be.
(For of that tribe are many.) One is she
That roars at midnight in deep tavern bowls,
That beats the watch, and constable's controls;
Another roars i'th day time, swears, stabs, gives braves,
Yet sells her soul to the lust of fools and slaves.
Both these are suburb-roarers. Then there's (Besides)
A civil city ▪ roaring girl, whose pride,
Feasting, and riding, shakes her husband's state,
And leaves him roaring through an iron grate.
None of these roaring girls is ours: she flies
With wings more lofty. Thus her character lies,
Yet what need characters? when to give a guess,
Is better than the person to express;
But would you know who 'tis? would you hear her name?
She is called mad Moll; her life, our acts proclaim.

list.head: Dramatis personae.
list.item: Sir Alexander Wentgrane, and neats-foot his man.
Jack dapper, and gull his page.

sp.stage: Enter Marry Fitz-allard disguised like a sempster with a case for bands, and Neatfoot a servingman with her, with a napkin on his shoulder, and a trencher in his hand as from table.

sp.speaker: Neatfoote.
sp.p: The young gentleman (Our young master) sir Alexander's son, is it into his ears (Sweet damsel) (Emblem of fragility) you desire to have a message transported, or to be transcendent.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: A private word or two sir, nothing else.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.p: You shall fructify in that which you come for: your pleasure shall be satisfied to your full contentation: I will (Fairest tree of generation) watch when our young master is erected, (That is to say up) and deliver him to this your most white hand.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Thanks sir.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.p: And withal certify him, that I have culled out for him (Now his belly is replenished) a daintier bit or modicum then any lay upon his trencher at dinner — hath he notion of your name, I beseech your chastity.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: One sir, of whom he be spoken falling bands.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.p: Falling bands, it shall so be given him, — — if you please to venture your modesty in the hall, amongst a curl-pated company of rude serving-men, and take such as they can set before you, you shall be most seriously, and ingeniously welcome.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: I have died indeed already sir.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.p: — — or will you vouchsafe to kiss the lip of a cup of rich Orleans in the buttery amongst our waiting women.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Not now in truth sir.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.p: Our young master shall then have a feeling of your being here presently it shall so be given him.

sp.speaker: Marry
sp.l: I humbly thank you sir, but that my bosom
Is full of bitter sorrows, I could smile,
To see this formal ape play antic tricks:
But in my breast a poisoned arrow sticks,
And smiles cannot become me, love woven slightly
(Such as thy false heart makes) wears out as lightly,
But love being truly bred ith' the soul (Like mine)
Bleeds even to death, at the least wound it takes,
The more we quench this, the less it slakes: o me!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A sempster speak with me, sayest thou.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.p: Yes sir, she's there, viva voce, to deliver her auricular confession.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: With me sweet heart. What is't?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: I have brought home your bands sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Bands: Neatfoot.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Prithee look in, for all the gentlemen are upon rising.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.l: Yes sir, a most methodical attendance shall be given.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: And dost hear, if my father call for me, say I am busy with a sempster.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.p: Yes sir, he shall know it that you are busied with a needle woman.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: In's ear good Neatfoot,

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.l: It shall be so given him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Bands, you're mistaken sweet heart, I bespoke none, when, where, I prithee, what bands, let me see them.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Yes sir, a bond fast sealed, with solemn oaths,
Subscribed unto (As I thought) with your soul:
Delivered as your deed in sight of heaven,
Is this bond cancelled, have you forgotten me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ha! life of my life: sir Guy Fitz-allard's daughter,
What has transformed my love to this strange shape?
Stay: make all sure, — so: now speak and be brief,
Because the wolf's at door that lies in wait,
To prey upon us both albeit mine eyes
Are blessed by thine, yet this so strange disguise
Holds me with fear and wonder.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Mine's a loathed sight,
Why from it are you banished else so long.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I must cut short my speech, in broken language,
Thus much sweet Moll, I must thy company shun,
I court another Moll, my thoughts must run,
As a horse runs, that's blind, round in a mill,
Out every step, yet keeping one path still.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Umh: must you shun my company, in one knot
Have both our hands byth' hands of heaven been tied,
Now to be broke, I thought me once your bride:
Our fathers did agree on the time when,
And must another bedfellow fill my room.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sweet maid, let's lose no time, 'tis in heaven's book
Set down, that I must have thee: an oath we took,
To keep our vows, but when the knight your father
Was from mine parted, storms began to sit
Upon my covetous father's brow: which fell
From them on me, he reckoned up what gold
This marriage would draw from him, at which he swore,
To lose so much blood, could not grieve him more.
He then dissuades me from thee, called thee not fair,
And asked what is she, but a beggar's heir?
He scorned thy dowry of (5000) marks.
If such a sum of money could be found,
And I would match with that, he'd not undo it,
Provided his bags might add nothing to it,
But vowed, if I took thee, nay more, did swear it,
Save birth from him I nothing should inherit.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: What follows then, my shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Dearest no:
Though wildly in a labyrinth I go,
My end is to meet thee: with a side wind
Must I now sail, else I no haven can find
But both must sink for ever. There's a wench
Called Moll, mad Moll, or merry Moll, a creature
So strange in quality, a whole city takes
Note of her name and person, all that affection
I owe to thee, on her in counterfeit passion,
I spend to mad my father: he believes
I dote upon this roaring girl, and grieves
As it becomes a father for a son,
That could be so bewitched: yet I'll go on
This crooked way, sigh still for her, fain dreams,
In which I'll talk only of her, these streams
Shall, I hope, force my father to consent
That here I anchor rather than be rent
Upon a rock so dangerous, art thou pleased,
Because thou seest we are waylaid, that I take
A path that's safe, though it be far about,

sp.speaker: Marry
sp.l: My prayers with heaven guide thee,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Then I will on,
My father is at hand, kiss and begone;
Hours shall be watched for meetings; I must now
As men for fear, to a strange I doll bow.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'll guide thee forth, when next we meet,
A story of Moll shall make our mirth more sweet.
sp.stage: Enter sir Alexander Wengraue, sir Davy dapper, sir Adam Appleton, Goshake, Laxton, and gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Thanks good sir Alexander for our bounteous cheer:

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Fie, fie, in giving thanks you pay too dear.

sp.speaker: S. Dap.
sp.l: When bounty spreads the table, faith 'twere sin,
(At going of) if thanks should not step in.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No more of thanks, no more, I marry sir,
Th'inner room was too close, how do you like
This parlour gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: O passing well.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.l: What a sweet breath the air casts here, so cool,

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: I like the prospect best.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: See how 'tis furnished.

sp.speaker: S. Dap.
sp.l: A very fair sweet room.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Sir Davy dapper,
The furniture that doth adorn this room,
Cost many a fair grey groat ere it came here,
But good things are most cheap, when they're most dear,
Nay when you look into my galleries,
How bravely they are trimmed up, you all shall swear
You're highly pleased to see what's set down there:
Storeys of men and women (Mixed together
Fair ones with foul, like sunshine in wet weather)
Within one square a thousand heads are laid
So close, that all of heads, the room seems made,
As many faces there (Filled with blithe looks)
Show like the promising titles of new books,
(Writ merrily) the readers being their own eyes,
Which seem to move and to give plaudities,
And here and there (Whilst with obsequious ears,
Thronged heaps do listen) a cut purse thrusts and leers
With hawk's eyes for his prey: I need not show him,
By a hanging villainous look, yourselves may know him,
The face is drawn so rarely, than sir below,
The very flower (As 'twere) waves to and fro,
And like a floating island, seems to move,
Upon a sea bound in with shores above,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: These sights are excellent.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I'll show you all,
Since we are met, make our parting comical.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This gentleman (My friend) will take his leave sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ha, take his leave (Sebastian) who?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This gentleman.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Your love sir, has already given me some time,
And if you please to trust my age with more,
It shall pay double interest: good sir stay.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.l: I have been too bold.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Not so sir. A merry day
Amongst friends being spent, is better than gold saved.
Some wine, some wine. Where be these knaves I keep.
sp.stage: Enter three or four serving-men, and Neatfoote.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.l: At your worshipful elbow, sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: You are kissing my maids, drinking, or fast asleep.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.l: Your worship has given it us right.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: You varlets stir,
Chairs, stools and cushions: prithee sir Davy dapper,
Make that chair thine.

sp.speaker: Sir Dap.
sp.l: 'Tis but an easy gift,
And yet I thank you for it sir, I'll take it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: A chair for old sir Adam Appleton.

sp.speaker: Neat.
sp.l: A back friend to your worship.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Marry good Neatfoot,
I thank thee for it: back friends sometimes are good.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Pray make that stool your perch, good m. goshawk.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: I stoop to your lure sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Son Sebastian,
Take master Greenwit to you.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sit dear friend.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Nay master Laxton — furnish master Laxton
With what he wants (A stone) a stool I would say, a stool.

sp.speaker: Laxton.
sp.l: I had rather stand sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I know you had (Good m. Laxton.) So, so —
Now here's a mess of friends, and (Gentlemen)
Because time's glass shall not be running long,
I'll quicken it with a pretty tale.

sp.speaker: Sir Dap.
sp.l: Good tales do well,
In these bad days, where vice does so excel.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Begin sir Alexander.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Last day I met
An aged man upon whose head was scored,
A debt of just so many years as these,
Which I owe to my grave, the man you all know.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: His name I pray you sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Nay you shall pardon me,
But when he saw me (With a sigh that broke,
Or seemed to break his heartstrings) thus he spoke:
O my good knight, says he, (And then his eyes
Were richer even by that which made them poor,
They had spent so many tears they had no more.)
O sir (Says he) you know it, for you ha' seen
Blessings to rain upon mine house and me:
Fortune (Who slaves men) was my slave: her wheel
Hath spun me golden threads, for I thank heaven,
I ne'er had but one cause to curse my stars,
I asked him then, what that one cause might be.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: He paused, and as we often see,
A sea so much becalmed, there can be found
No wrinkle on his brow, his waves being drowned
In their own rage: but when th'imperious wind,
Use strange invisible tyranny to shake
Both heavens and earth's foundation at their noise:
The seas swelling with wrath to part that fray
Rise up, and are more wild, more mad, than they.
Even so this good old man was by my question
Stirred up to roughness, you might see his gall
Flow even in's eyes: then grew he fantastical.

sp.speaker: Sir Dap.
sp.l: Fantastical, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Yes, and talk oddly.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Pray sir proceed,
How did this old man end?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Marry sir thus.
He left his wild fit to read o'er his cards,
Yet then (Though age cast snow on all his hairs)
He joyed because (Says he) the god of gold
Has been to me no niggard: that disease
(Of which all old men sicken) avarice
Never infected me.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: He means not himself I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: For like a lamp,
Fed with continual oil, I spend and throw
My light to all that need it, yet have still
Enough to serve myself, o but (Quoth he)
Though heavens-dew fall, thus on this aged tree,
I have a son that's like a wedge doth cleave,
My very heart root,

sp.speaker: S, Dap.
sp.l: Had he such a son,

sp.speaker: Seb,
sp.l: Now I do smell a fox strongly.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Let's see: no master Greenwit is not yet
So mellow in years as he; but as like Sebastian,
Just like my son Sebastian, — such another.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: How finely like a fencer my father fetches his by-blows to hit me, but if I beat you not at your own weapon of subtlety.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: This son (Saith he) that should be
The column and main arch unto my house,
The crutch unto my age, becomes a whirlwind
Shaking the firm foundation,

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.l: 'Tis some prodigal.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Well shot old Adam bell.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No city monster neither, no prodigal,
But sparing, wary, civil, and (Though wifeless)
An excellent husband, and such a traveller,
He has more tongues in his head then some have teeth,

sp.speaker: S. Dap.
sp.l: I have but two in mine

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: So sparing and so wary,
What then could vex his father so.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O a woman.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A flesh fly, that can vex any man.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: A scurvy woman,
On whom the passionate old man swore he doted:
A creature (Saith he) nature hath brought forth
To mock the sex of woman. — it is a thing
One knows not how to name, her birth began
Ere she was all made. 'tis woman more than man,
Man more than woman, and (Which to none can hap)
The sun gives her two shadows to one shape,
Nay more, let this strange thing, walk, stand or sit,
No blazing star draws more eyes after it.

sp.speaker: S. Dap.
sp.l: A monster, 'tis some monster.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: She's a varlet.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Now is my cue to bristle.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: A naughty pack.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ha boy.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: What's false, I say she's naught.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I say that tongue
That dares speak so (But yours) sticks in the throat
Of a rank villain, set yourself aside. —

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: So sir what then.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Any here else had lied.
I think I shall fit you —

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Lie.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Dap.
sp.l: Doth this concern him.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ah sirrah boy.
Is your blood heated: boils it: are you stung,
I'll pierce you deeper yet: o my dear friends,
I am that wretched father, this that son,
That sees his ruin, yet headlong on doth run.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Will you love such a poison.

sp.speaker: S. Dap.
sp.l: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You're all mad.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Thou'rt sick at heart, yet feelst it not: of all these,
What gentleman (But thou) knowing his disease
mortal, would shun the cure: o master Greenwit,
Would you to such an idol bow.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.l: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Here's master Laxton, has he mind to a woman
As thou hast.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: No not I sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Sir I know it.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: There good parts are so rare, there bade so common,
I will have naught to do with any woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Dap.
sp.l: 'Tis well done master Laxton.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O thou cruel boy,
Thou wouldst with lust an old man's life destroy,
Because thou seest I'm half way in my grave,
Thou shovel'st dust upon me: would thou mightest have
Thy wish, most wicked, most unnatural.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Why sir, 'tis thought, sir Guy Fitz-allard's daughter
Shall wed your son Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Sir Davy dapper.
I have upon my knees, wood this fond boy,
To take that virtuous maiden.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hark you a word sir.
You on your knees have cursed that virtuous maiden,
And me for loving her, yet do you now
Thus baffle me to my face: were not your knees
In such entreats, give me Fitz-allard's daughter.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I'll give thee ratsbane rather.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Well then you know
What dish I mean to feed upon.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Hark gentlemen,
He swears to have this cutpurse drab, to spite my gall.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Master Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I am deaf to you all.
I'm so bewitched, so bound to my desires,
Tears, prayers, threats, nothing can quench out those fires
That burn within me.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Her blood shall quench it then,
Lose him not, o dissuade him gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Dap.
sp.l: He shall be weaned I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Before his eyes
Lay down his shame, my grief, his miseries.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: No more, no more, away.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I wash a negro,
Losing both pains and cost: but take thy flight,
I'll be most near thee, when I'm least in sight.
Wild buck I'll hunt thee breathless, thou shalt run on,
But I will turn thee when I'm not thought upon.
Now sirrah what are you, leave your ape's tricks and speak.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: A letter from my captain to your worship.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: O, o, now I remember 'tis to prefer thee into my service.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: To be a shifter under your worship's nose of a clean trencher, when there's a good bit upon't.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Troth honest fellow — humh — ha — let me see,
This knave shall be the axe to hew that down
At which I stumble, has a face that promiseth
Much of a villain, I will grind his wit,
And if the edge prove fine make use of it.
Come hither sirrah, canst thou be secret, ha.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: As two crafty attorneys plotting the undoing of their clients.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Didst never, as thou hast walked about this town
Hear of a wench called Moll, mad merry Moll.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Moll cutpurse sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The same, dost thou know her then,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: As well as I know 'twill rain upon Simon and Jude's day next, I will sift all the taverns ith' city, and drink half pots with all the watermen ath' Bankside, but if you will sir I'll find her out.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: That task is easy, do't then, hold thy hand up.
What's this, is't burned?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: No sir no, a little singed with making fire works.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: There's money, spend it, that being spent fetch more.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
O sir that all the poor soldiers in England had
such a leader. For fetching no water spaniel is like me.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: This wench we speak of, strays so from her kind
Nature repents she made her. 'tis a mermaid
Has told my son to shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I'll cut her comb for you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I'll tell out gold for thee then: hunt her forth,
Cast out a line hung full of silver hooks
To catch her to thy company: deep spendings
May draw her that's most chaste to a man's bosom.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: The gingling of golden bells, and a good fool with a hobby-horse, will draw all the whores ith' town to dance in a morris,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Or rather, for that's best, (They say sometimes
She goes in breeches) follow her as her man.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: And when her breeches are off, she shall follow me.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Beat all thy brains to serve her.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Zounds sir, as country wenches beat cream, till butter comes.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Play thou the subtle spider, weave fine nets
To ensnare her very life.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Her life.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Yes suck
Her heartblood if thou canst, twist thou but cords
To catch her, I'll find law to hang her up.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Spoken like a worshipful bencher.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Trace all her steps: at this she-fox's den
Watch what lambs enter: let me play the shepherd
To save their throats from bleeding, and cut hers.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: This is the goll shall do't.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Be firm and gain me
Ever thine own. This done I entertain thee:
How is thy name.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: My name sir is Raph Trapdore, honest Raph.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Trapdore, be like thy name, a dangerous step
For her to venture on, but unto me.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: As fast as your sole to your boot or shoe sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Hence then, be little seen here as thou canst.
I'll still be at thine elbow.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: The trapdoors set.
Moll if you budge you're gone: this me shall crown,
A roaring boy, the roaring girl puts down,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: God a mercy, lose no time.
sp.stage: The three shops open in a rank: the first a pothecary's shop, the next a feather shop: the third a sempster's shop: mistress Gallipot in the first, mistress Tiltyard in the next, master Openworke and his wife in the third, to them enters Laxton, goshawk and Greenwit.

sp.speaker: Mi Open.
sp.p: Gentlemen what is't you lack. What is't you buy, see fine bands and ruffs, fine lawns, fine cambrics, what is't you lack gentlemen, what is't you buy?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Yonder's the shop.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Is that she.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Green
sp.l: She that minces tobacco.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: I: she's a gentlewoman born I can tell you, though it be her hard fortune now to shred Indian potherbs.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: O sir 'tis many a good woman's fortune, when her husband turns bankrupt, to begin with pipes and set up again.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: And indeed the raising of the woman is the lifting up of the man's head at all times, if one flourish, tother will bud as fast I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Come thou'rt familiarly acquainted there, I grope that.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: And you grope no better ith' dark you may chance lie ith' ditch when you're drunk.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Go thou'rt a mystical lecher.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: I will not deny but my credit may take up an ounce of pure smoke.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p:
May take up an ell of pure smock; away go, 'tis the closest striker. Life I think he commits venery 40 foot deep, no man's aware on't, I like a palpable smockster go to work so openly, with the tricks of art, that I'm as apparently seen as a naked boy in a vial, and were it not for a gift of treachery that I have in me to betray my friend when he puts most trust in me (Mass yonder
he is too —) and by his injury to make good my access to her, I should appear as defective in courting, as a farmer's son the first day of his feather, that doth nothing at court, but woe the hangings and glass windows for a month together, and some broken waiting woman for ever after. I find those imperfections in my venery, that were't not for flattery and falsehood, I should want discourse and impudence, and he that wants impudence among women, is worthy to be kicked out at bed's feet. — he shall not see me yet.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.l: Troth this is finely shred.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: O women are the bèst mincers.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: 'Thad been a good phrase for a cook's wife sir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: But 'twill serve generally, like the front of a new almanac; as thus: calculated for the meridian of cook's wives, but generally for all Englishwomen.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Nay you shall have't sir, I have filled it for you.
sp.stage: She puts it to the fire.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: The pipe's in a good hand, and I wish mine always so.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.l: But not to be used a that fashion.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: O pardon me sir, I understand no French.
I pray be covered. Jack a pipe of rich smoke.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Rich smoke; that's 6. pence a pipe is't?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.l: To me sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Be not forgetful; respect my credit; seem strange;
Art and wit makes a fool of suspicion: — pray be wary.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Push, I warrant you: — come, how is't gallants?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.l: Pure and excellent.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: I thought 'twas good, you were grown so silent; you are like those that love not to talk at victuals, though they make a worse noise i'the nose then a common fiddler's prentice, and discourse a whole supper with snuffling; — I must speak a word with you anon.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Make your way wisely then. (Ners,

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: O what else sir, he's perfection itself, full of man -
But not an acre of ground belonging to 'em.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I and full of form, has never a good stool in's chamber.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: But above all religious: he prayeth daily upon elder brothers.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: And valiant above measure; has run three streets from a sergeant.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Puh, puh.
sp.stage: He blows tobacco in their faces.

sp.speaker: Green. Gosh.
sp.l: O, puh, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: What's the matter now sir?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: I protest I'm in extreme want of money, if you can supply me now with any means, you do me the greatest pleasure, next to the bounty of your love, as ever poor gentleman tasted.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: What's the sum would pleasure ye sir?
Though you deserve nothing less at my hands.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Why 'tis but for want of opportunity thou knowest; I put her off with opportunity still: by this light I hate her, but for means to keep me in fashion with gallants; for what I take from her, I spend upon other wenches, bear her in hand still; she has wit enough to rob her husband, and I ways enough to consume the money: why how now? what the chincough?

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: Thou hast the cowardliest trick to come before a man's face and strangle him ere he be aware, I could find in my heart to make a quarrel in earnest.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Pox and thou dost, thou knowest I never use to fight with my friends, thou'lt but lose thy labour in't. Jack dapper!
sp.stage: Enter I. dapper, and his man gull.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.l: Monsieur dapper, I dive down to your ankles.

sp.speaker: I. Dap.
sp.l: Save ye gentlemen all three in a peculiar salute.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: He were ill to make a lawyer, he dispatches three at once.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: So well said: but is this of the same tobacco mistress Gallipot?

sp.speaker: M. Gal.
sp.l: The same you had at first sir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: I wish it no better: this will serve to drink at my chamber.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Shall we taste a pipe on't?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Not of this by my troth gentlemen, I have sworn before you.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: What not Jack dapper.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Pardon me sweet Jack, I'm sorry I made such a rash oath, but foolish oaths must stand: where art going Jack.

sp.speaker: Jac. Dap.
sp.l: Faith to buy one feather.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: One feather, the fool's peculiar still.

sp.speaker: Jac. Dap.
sp.l: Gul.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.l: Master.

sp.speaker: Jac. Dap.
sp.p: Here's three halfpence for your ordinary, boy, meet me an hour hence in Paul's.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: How three single halfpence; life, this will scarce serve a man in sauce, a halporth of mustard, a halporth of oil, and a halporth of vinegar, what's left then for the pickle herring: this shows like final beer ith' morning after a great surfeit of wine o'er night, he could spend his three pound last night in a supper amongst girls and brave bawdy-house boys, I thought his pockets cackled not for nothing, these are the eggs of three pound, I'll go sup 'em up presently.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Fight, nine, ten angles, good wench i'faith, and one that loves darkness well, she puts out a candle with the best tricks of any drugster's wife in England: but that which mads her I rail upon opportunity still, and take no notice on't. The other night she would needs lead me into a room with a candle in her hand to show me a naked picture, where no sooner entered but the candle was sent of an arrant: now I not intending to understand her, but like a puny at the inns of venery, called for another light innocently, thus reward I all her cunning with simple mistaking. I know she cozens her husband to keep me, and I'll keep her honest, as long as I can, to make the poor man some part of amends, an honest mind of a whoremaster, how think you amongst you, what a fresh pipe, draw in a third man.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: No your a hoarder, you engross byth' ounces.

sp.speaker: Jac. Dap.
sp.l: Puh I like it not.

sp.speaker: M. Tiltyard
sp.l: What feather is't you'd have sir.
These are most worn and most in fashion,
Amongst the beaver gallants the stone riders.
The private stage's audience, the twelve penny stool gentlemen,
I can inform you 'tis the general feather.

sp.speaker: Jac. Dap.
sp.l: And therefore I mislike it, tell me of general.
Now a continual Simon and Jude's rain
Beat all your feathers as flat down as pancakes.
Show me — — a — spangled feather,

sp.speaker: Mistress Tilt.
sp.l: O to go a feasting with,
You'd have it for a hench boy, you shall.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Mass I had quite forgotten,
His honour's footman was here last night wife,
Ha you done with my lord's shirt.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: What's that to you sir,
I was this morning at his honour's lodging,
Ere such a snake as you crept out of your shell.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: O 'twas well done good wife.

sp.speaker: Mt. Op.
sp.l: I hold it better sir, then if you had don't yourself.

sp.speaker: Ma. Op.
sp.p: Nay so say I: but is the countess's smock almost done mouse.

sp.speaker: Mi Op.
sp.l: Here lies the cambric sir, but wants I fear me.

sp.speaker: Ma. Op.
sp.l: I'll resolve you of that presently,

sp.speaker: Mi Op.
sp.l: Haida, o audacious groom,
Dare you presume to noble women's linen,
Keep you your yard to measure shepherd's holland,
I must confine you I see that.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: What say you to this gear.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: I dare the arrant'st critic in tobacco
To lay one fault upon't.
sp.stage: Enter Mol in a freeze jerkin and a black safeguard.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Life yonder's Moll.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Moll which Moll.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Honest Moll.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Prithee let's call her — Moll.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Moll, Moll, pist Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: How now, what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: A pipe of good tobacco Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Nay Moll puh, prithee hark, but one word i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Well what is't.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.l: Prithee come hither sirrah.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Heart I would give but too much money to be nibbling with that wench, life, sh'as the spirit of four great parishes, and a voice that will drown all the city, methinks a brave captain might get all his soldiers upon her, and ne'er be beholding to a company of Mile-end milk sops, if he could come on, and come off quick enough: such a Moll were a marrowbone before an Italian, he would cry bona roba till his ribs were nothing but bone. I'll lay hard siege to her, money is that aqua fortis, that eats into many a maidenhead, where the walls are flesh and blood I'll ever pierce through with a golden auger.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Now thy judgement Moll, is't not good?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Yes faith 'tis very good tobacco, how do you sell an an ounce, farewell. God b'y you mistress Gallipot,

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Why Moll, mol.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: I cannot stay now i'faith, I am going to buy a shag cuff, the shop will be shut in presently.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: 'Tis the maddest fantasticalst girl: — I never knew so much flesh and so much nimbleness put together.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: She slips from one company to another, like a fat eel between a Dutchman's fingers: — I'll watch my time for her.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Some will not stick to say she's a man
And some both man and woman.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: That were excellent, she might first cuckold the husband and then make him do as much for the wife.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Save you; how does mistress Tiltyard?

sp.speaker: I. Dap.
sp.l: Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Jack Dappper.

sp.speaker: I. Dap.
sp.l: How dost Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I'll tell thee by and by, I go but toth' next shop.

sp.speaker: I. Dap.
sp.l: Thou shalt find me here this hour about a feather.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Nay and a feather hold you in play a whole hour, a goose will last you all the days of your life. Let me see a good shag ruff.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.p: Mistress marry that shalt thou i'faith, and the best in the shop.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: How now, greetings, love terms with a pox between you, have I found out one of your haunts, I send you for hollands, and you're ith' the low countries with a mischief, I'm served with good ware byth' shift, that makes it lie dead so long upon my hands, I were as good shut up shop, for when I open it I take nothing.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.p: Nay and you fall a ringing once the devil cannot stop you, I'll out of the belfry as fast as I can — Moll.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Get you from my shop.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I come to buy. (Shop

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: I'll sell ye nothing, I warn ye my house and

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: You goody Openwork, you that prick out a poor living
And sows many a bawdy skin-coat together,
Thou private panderess between shirt and smock,
I wish thee for a minute but a man:
Thou shouldst never use more shapes, but as thou'rt
I pity my revenge, now my spleens up,
sp.stage: Enter a fellow with a long rapier by his side.
sp.l: I would not mock it willingly — ha be thankful.
Now I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Marry hang thee, I never asked forgiveness in my life.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: You goodman swinesface.

sp.speaker: Fellow
sp.l: What will you murder me.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: You remember slave, how you abused me tother night in a tavern.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Not I by this light.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: No, but by candlelight you did, you have tricks to save your oaths, reservations have you, and I have reserved somewhat for you, — as you like that call for more, you know the sign again.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p:
Pox ant, had I brought any company along with me to have born witless on't, 'twould never have grieved me, but to be struck and nobody by, 'tis my ill fortune still, why tread upon a worm they say 'twill turn tail, but indeed a gentleman
should have more manners.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Gallantly performed ifath Moll, and manfully, I love thee for ever fort, base rogue, had he offered but the least counterbuff, by this hand I was prepared for him.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: You prepared for him, why should you be prepared for him, was he any more than a man.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: No nor so much by a yard and a handful London measure ..

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Why do you speak this then, do you think I cannot ride a stone horse, unless one lead him byth' snaffle.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Yes and sit him bravely, I know thou canst Moll, 'twas but an honest mistake through love, and I'll make amends fort any way, prithee sweet plump Moll, when shall thou and I go out a town together.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Whether to Tyburn prithee.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Mass that's out a town indeed, thou hangest so many jests upon thy friends still. I mean honestly to Brainford, Staines or ware.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: What to do there.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Nothing but be merry and lie together, I'll hire a coach with four horses.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: I thought 'twould be a beastly journey, you may leave out one well, three horses will serve, if I play the jade myself.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Nay push thou'rt such another kicking wench, prithee be kind and let's meet.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: 'Tis hard but we shall meet sir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Nay but appoint the place then, there's ten angels in fair gold Moll, you see I do not trifle with you, do but say thou wilt meet me, and I'll have a coach ready for thee.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Why here's my hand I'll meet you sir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: O good gold, — the place sweet Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: It shall be your appointment.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Somewhat near Holborn Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: In Grays-inn fields then.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: A match.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I'll meet you there.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: The hour.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Three.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: That will be time enough to sup at Brainford.
sp.stage: Fall from them to the other.

sp.speaker: Ma. Op.
sp.p: I am of such a nature sir, I cannot endure the house when she scolds, she's a tongue will be hard further in a still morning than saint Antlings-bell, she rails upon me for foreign wenching, that I being a freeman must needs keep a whore ith' suburbs, and seek to impoverish the liberties, when we fall out, I trouble you still to make all whole with my wife.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: No trouble at all, 'tis a pleasure to me to join things together.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.p: Go thy ways, I do this but to try thy honesty goshawk.

sp.speaker: Jac. Dap.
sp.l: How likest thou this Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: O singularly, your fitted now for a bunch, he looks for all the world with those spangled feathers like a nobleman's bedpost: the purity of your wench would I fain try, she seems like Kent unconquered, and I believe as many wiles are in her — o the gallants of these times are shallow lechers, they put not their courtship home enough to a wench, 'tis impossible to know what woman is thoroughly honest, because she's never thoroughly tried, I am of that certain belief there are more queans in this town of their own making, then of any man's provoking, where lies the slackness then? many a poor soul would down, and there's nobody will push women are courted but never soundly tried, ('em: as many walk in spurs that never ride.

sp.speaker: Mrs., Open.
sp.l: O abominable.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: Nay more I tell you in private, he keeps a whore ith' suburbs.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: O spittle dealing, I came to him a gentlewoman born. I'll show you mine arms when you please sir.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: I had rather see your legs, and begin that way.

sp.speaker: Mistress Openworke
sp.p: 'Tis well known he took me from a lady's service, where I was well beloved of the steward, I had my Latin tongue, and a spice of the French before I came to him, and now doth he keep a suburbian whore under my nostrils.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: There's ways enough to cry quite with him, hark in thine ear.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: There's a friend worth a million.

sp.speaker: Mol
sp.l: I'll try one spear against your chastity mist. Tiltyard
Though it prove too short by the burgh.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Mass here she is. Enter Ralph TrapdoreI'm bound already to serve her, though it be but a sluttish trick. Bless my hopeful young mistress with long life and great limbs, send her the upper hand of all bailiffs, and their hungry adherents.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: How now, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: A poor ebbing gentleman, that would gladly wait for the young flood of your service.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: My service! what should move you to offer your service to me sir?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: The love I bear to your heroic spirit and masculine womanhood.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: So sir, put case we should retain you to us, what parts are there in you for a gentlewoman's service.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Of two kinds right worshipful: movable, and immovable: movable to run of errands, and immovable to stand when you have occasion to use me.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: What strength have you.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Strength mistress Moll, I have gone up into a steeple, and stayed the great bell as 'thas been ringing; stopped a windmill going.
sp.stage: Mols trips up his heels he falls.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: And never struck down yourself.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Stood as upright as I do at this present.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Come I pardon you for this, it shall be no disgrace to you: I have struck up the heels of the high Germans size ere now, — what not stand.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I am of that nature where I love, I'll be at my mistress foot to do her service.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Why well said, but say your mistress should receive injury, have you the spirit of fighting in you, durst you second her.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Life I have kept a bridge myself, and drove seven
at a time before me.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: But they were all Lincolnshire bullocks by my troth.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Well, meet me in Grays-inn fields, between three and four this afternoon, and upon better consideration we'll retain you.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I humbly thank your good mistress-ship,
I'll crack your neck for this kindness.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Remember three.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Nay if I fail you hang me.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Good wench i'faith.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Who's this.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: 'Tis I Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Prithee tend thy shop and prevent bastards.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: We'll have a pint of the same wine i'faith Moll.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Hark the bell rings, come gentlemen.
Jack dapper where shall's all munch.

sp.speaker: Jae. Dap.
sp.l: I am for Parker's ordinary.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: He's a good guest to'm, he deserves his board,
He draws all the gentlemen in a term time thither,
We'll be your follower's Jack, lead the way,
Look you by my faith the fool has feathered his nest well.
sp.stage: Enter master Gallipot, master Tiltyard, and servants with water spaniels and a duck.

sp.speaker: Maist. Tilt.
sp.p: Come shut up your shops, where's master Openwork.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Nay ask not me master Tiltyard.

sp.speaker: Maist. Tilt.
sp.l: Where's his water dog, puh — pist — her — hur-pist

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: Come wenches come, we're going all to Hogsden.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: To Hogsden husband.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: I to Hogsden pigs nigh.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: I'm not ready husband.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Faith that's well — hum — pist — pist.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Come mistress Openwork you are so long.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: I have no joy of my life master Gallipot.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal,
sp.p: Push, let your boy lead his water spaniel along, and we'll show you the bravest sport at perilous pond, he trug, he trug, he trug, here's the best duck in England, except my wife, he, he, he, fetch, fetch, fetch, come let's away of all the year this is the sportfulst day.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: If a man have a free will, where should the use
More perfect shine then in his will to love.
All creatures have their liberty in that,
sp.stage: Enter sir Alexander and listens to him.
sp.l: Though else kept under servile yoke and fear,
The very bondslave has his freedom there,
Amongst a world of creatures voiced and silent.
Must my desires wear fetters — yea are you
So near, than I must break with my heart's truth;
Meet grief at a back way — well: why suppose.
The two lewd tongues of slander or of truth
Pronounce Moll loathsome: if before my love
She appear fair, what injury have I,
I have the thing I like? in all things else
Mine own eye guides me, and I find 'em prosper,
Life what should ail it now? I know that man
Near truly loves, if he gainsay't he lies,
That winks and marries with his father's eyes.
I'll keep mine own wide open.
sp.stage: Enter Mol and a porter with a viallon his back.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Here's brave wilfulness,
'A made match, here she comes, they met a purpose.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: Must I carry this great fiddle to your chamber mistress Mary.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Fiddle goodman hog-rubber, some of these porters bear so much for others, they have no time to carry wit for themselves.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.l: To your own chamber mistress Mary.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p:
Who'll hear an ass speak: whither else goodman
pageant-bearer: they're people of the worst memories.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Why 'twere too great a burden love, to have them carry things in their minds, and at her backs together.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, I thought not you so near.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: So, so, so.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I would be nearer to thee, and in that fashion,
That makes the best part of all creatures honest.
No otherwise I wish it.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Sir I am so poor to requite you, you must look for nothing but thanks of me, I have no humour to marry, I love to lie aboth sides ath' bed myself; and again ath' other side, a wife you know ought to be obedient, but I fear me I am too headstrong to obey, therefore I'll ne'er go about it, I love you so well sir for your good will I'd be loath you should repent your bargain after, and therefore we'll never come together at first, I have the head now of myself, and am man enough for a woman, marriage is but a chopping and changing, where a maiden loses one head, and has a worse ith' place.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: The most comfortablest answer from a roaring girl, that ever mine ears drunk in.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: This were enough now to affright a fool for ever from thee, when 'tis the music that I love thee for,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: There's a boy spoils all again.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Believe it sir I am not of that disdainful temper, but
I could love you faithfully.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: A pox on you for that word. I like you not now,
You're a cunning roarer I see that already.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: But sleep upon this once more sir, you may chance shift a mind tomorrow, be not too hasty to wrong yourself, never while you live sir take a wife running, many have run out at heels that have don't: you see sir I speak against myself, and if every woman would deal with their suitor so honestly, poor younger brothers would not be so often guled with old cozening widows, that turn o'er all their wealth in trust to some kinsman, and make the poor gentleman work hard for a pension, fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nay prithee one word more.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: How do I wrong this girl, she puts him of still.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Think upon this in cold blood sir, you make as much haste as if you were a going upon a sturgeon voyage, take deliberation sir, never choose a wife as if you were going to Virginia.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And so we parted, my too cursed fate.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: She is but cunning, gives him longer time in't.

sp.speaker: Taylor
sp.l: Mistress Moll, mistress Moll: so ho ho so ho.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: There boy, there boy, what dost thou go a hawking after me with a red clout on thy finger.

sp.speaker: Taylor
sp.p: I forgotten to take measure on you for your new breeches.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hoyda breeches, what will he marry a monster with two trinkets, what age is this? if the wife go in breeches, the man must wear long coats like a fool.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: What fidlings here, would not the old pattern have served your turn.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: You change the fashion, you say you'll have the great Dutch slop mistress Mary.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Why sir I say so still.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: Your breeches then will take up a yard more.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Well pray look it be put in then.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: It shall stand round and full I warrant you,

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Pray make 'em easy enough.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I know my fault now, tother was somewhat stiff between the legs, I'll make these open enough I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Here's good gear towards, I have brought up my son to marry a Dutch slop,. and a French doublet, a codpiece daughter.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: So, I have gone as far as I can go.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Why then farewell.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: If you go presently to your chamber mistress marry, pray send me the measure of your thigh, by some honest body.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Well sir, I'll send it by a porter presently.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: So you had need, it is a lusty one, both of them would make any porters back ache in England.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I have examined the best part of man,
Reason and judgement, and in love they tell me,
They leave me uncontrolled, he that is swayed
By an unfeeling blood, passed heat of love
His spring time must needs err, his watch ne'er goes right
That sets his dial by a rusty clock,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: So, and which is that rusty clock sir you.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The clock at Ludgate sir, it ne'er goes true.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: But thou goest falser: not thy father's cares
Can keep thee right, when that insensible work,
Obeys the workman's art, let's off the hour
And stops again when time is satisfied,
But thou runnest on, and judgement, thy main wheel,
Beats by all stops, as if the work would break
Begun with long pains for a minute's ruin,
Much like a suffering man brought up with care.
At last bequeathed to shame and a short prayer,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I taste you bitterer than I can deserve sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Who has bewitch thee son, what devil or drug,
Hath wrought upon the weakness of thy blood,
And betrayed all her hopes to ruinous folly?
O wake from drowsy and enchanted shame,
Wherein thy soul sits with a golden dream
Flattered and poisoned, I am old my son, (Mine own
O let me prevail quickly, for I have weightier business of
Then to chide thee: I must not to my grave,
As a drunkard to his bed, whereon he lies
Only to sleep, and never cares to rise,
Let me dispatch in time, come no more near her.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Not honestly, not in the way of marriage,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What sayst thou marriage, in what place, the session's house, and who shall give the bride, prithee, an indictment.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sir now ye take part with the world to wrong her.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Why, wouldst thou fain marry to be pointed at,
Alas the numbers great, do not o'er burden't,
Why as good marry a beacon on a hill,
Which all the country fix their eyes upon
As her thy folly dotes on. If thou longest
To have the story of thy infamous fortunes,
Serve for discourse in ordinaries and taverns
Thou'rt in the way: or to confound thy name,
Keep on, thou canst not miss it: or to strike
Thy wretched father to untimely coldness,
Keep the left hand still, it will bring thee to't.
Yet if no tears wrung from thy father's eyes,
Nor sighs that fly in sparkles, from his sorrows,
Had power to alter what is wilful in thee,
Methinks her very name should fright thee from her,
And never trouble me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why is the name of Moll so fatal sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Many one sir, where suspect is entered,
For seek all London from one end to tother,
More whores of that name, then of any ten other.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What's that to her? let those blush for themselves.
Can any guilt in others condemn her?
I've vowed to love her: let all storms oppose me,
That ever beat against the breast of man,
Nothing but death's black tempest shall divide us.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O folly that can dote on naught but shame.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Put case a wanton itch runs through one name
More than another, is that name the worse,
Where honesty sits possessed in't? it should rather
Appear more excellent, and deserve more praise,
When through foul mists a brightness it can raise.
Why there are of the devils, honest gentlemen,
And well descended, keep an open house,
And some ath' (Good man's) that are arrant knaves.
He hates unworthily, that by rote contemns,
For the name neither saves, nor yet condemns,
And for her honesty, I have made such proof an't,
in several forms, so nearly watched her ways,
I will maintain that strict, against an army,
Excepting you my father: here's her worst,
She's a bold spirit that mingles with mankind,
But nothing else comes near it: and oftentimes
Through her apparel somewhat shames her birth,
But she is loose in nothing but in mirth,
Would all molls were no worse.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: This way I toil in vain and give but aim
To infamy and ruin: he will fall,
My blessing cannot stay him: all my joys
Stand at the brink of a devouring flood
And will be wilfully swallowed: wilfully.
But why so vain, let all these tears be lost,
I'll pursue her to shame, and so all's crossed.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He is gone with some strange purpose, whose effect
Will hurt me little if he shoot so wide,
To think I love so blindly: I but feed
His heart to this match, to draw on th'other.
Wherein my joy sits with a full wish crowned;
Only his mood excepted which must change.
By opposite policies, courses indirect,
Plain dealing in this world takes no effect.
This mad girl I'll acquaint with my intent,
Get her assistance, make my fortunes known,
Twixt lovers hearts, she's a fit instrument,
And has the art to help them to their own,
By her advice, for in that craft she's wise,
My love and I may meet, spite of all spies.
sp.stage: Enter Laxton in Grays-inn fields with the coachman.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Coachman.

sp.speaker: Coachman
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: There's a tester more, prithee drive thy coach to the hither end of Marybone park, a fit place for Moll to get in.

sp.speaker: Coachman
sp.l: Marybone park fir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Ay, it's in our way thou knowest.

sp.speaker: Coachman
sp.l: It shall be done fir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Coachman.

sp.speaker: Coachman
sp.l: A non sir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Are we fitted with good frampold jades.

sp.speaker: Coachman
sp.l: The best in Smithfield I warrant your sir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: May we safely take the upper hand of any coached velvet cap or tuftaffety jacket, for they keep a vild swaggering in coaches now a day's, the high ways are stopped with them.

sp.speaker: Coachman
sp.p: My life for yours and baffle 'em to sir, — why they are the same jades believe it sir, that have drawn all your famous whores to Ware.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Nay then they know their business, they need no more instructions.

sp.speaker: Coachman
sp.p: They're so used to such journeys sir, I never use whip to 'em; for if they catch but the scent of a wench once, they run like devils.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Fine Cerberus, that rogue will have the start of a thousand ones, for whilst others trot a foot, he'll ride prancing to hell upon a coach-horse.

Stay, 'tis now about the hours of her appointment, but yet I see her not, hark what's this, one, two three, three by the clockthe clock strikes three. at Savoy, this is the hour, and Grays-inn fields the place, she swore she'd meet me: ha yonder's two inns a court-man with one wench, but that's not she, they walk towards Islington out of my way, I see none yet dressed like her, I must look for a shag ruff, a freeze jerkin, a shortsword, and a safeguard, or I get none: why Moll prithee make haste, or the coachman will curse us anon.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p:
O here's my gentleman: if they would keep their days as well with their mercers as their hours with their harlots, no bankrupt would give seven score pound for a sergeant's place, for would you know a catchpole rightly derived,
the corruption of a citizen, is the generation of a sergeant, how his eye hawks for venery. Come are you ready sir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Ready, for what sir.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Do you ask that now sir, why was this meeting pointed.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: I thought you mistook me sir,
You seem to be some young barrister,
I have no suit in law — all my land's sold
I praise heaven for't; t'has rid me of much trouble,

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Then I must wake you sir, where stands the coach,

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Who's this, Moll: honest Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: So young, and purblind, your an old wanton in your eyes I see that.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Thou'rt admirably suited for the three pigeons at Brainford, I'll swear I knew thee not.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I'll swear you did not: but you shall know me now.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: No not here, we shall be spied efaith, the coach is better, come.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: What wilt thou untruss a point Moll.
sp.stage: She puts of her cloak and draws.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Yes, here's the point that I untruss, 'thas but one tag, 'twill serve though to tie up a rogue's tongue.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: How. (Here's her pace,

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: There's the gold with which you hired your hackney,
She racks hard, and perhaps your bones will feel it,
Ten angels of mine own, I've put to thine, win 'em, and wear 'em,

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Hold Moll, mistress Mary.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Draw or I'll serve an execution on thee
Shall lay thee up till doom's day.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Draw upon a woman, why what dost mean Moll?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: To teach thy base thoughts manners: thou'rt one of those
That thinks each woman thy fond flexible whore,
If she but cast a liberal eye upon thee,
Turn back her head, she's thine, or amongst company,
By chance drink first to thee: then she's quite gone,
There's no means to help her: nay for a need,
Wilt swear unto thy credulous fellow lechers.
That thou'rt more in favour with a lady at first sight
Then her monkey all her life time,
How many of our sex, by such as thou
Have their good thoughts paid with a blasted name
That never deserved loosely or did trip
In path of whoredom, beyond cup and lip.
But for the stain of conscience and of soul,
Better had women fall into the hands
Of an act silent, than a bragging nothing,
There's no mercy in't — what durst move you sir,
To think me whorish? A name which I'd tear out
From the high Germans throat, if it lay ledger there
To dispatch privy slanders against me.
In thee I defy all men, there worst hates,
And their best flatteries, all their golden witchcrafts,
With which they entangle the poor spirits of fools,
Distressed needlewomen and trade-fallen wives.
Fish that must needs bite, or themselves be bitten,
Such hungry things as these may soon be taken
With a worm fastened on a golden hook.
Those are the lecher's food, his prey, he watches
For quarrelling wedlocks, and poor shifting sisters,
'Tis the best fish he takes: but why good fisherman,
Am I thought meat for you, that never yet
Had angling rod cast towards me? 'cause you'll say
I'm given to sport, I'm often merry, jest,
Had mirth no kindred in the world but lust?
O shame take all her friends then: but howe'er
Thou and the baser world censure my life,
I'll send 'em word by thee, and write so much
Upon thy breast, cause thou shalt bear't in mind,
Tell them 'twere base to yield, where I have conquered.
I scorn to prostitute myself to a man,
I that can prostitute a man to me,
And so I greet thee.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Hear me.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Would the spirits of all my slanders, were clasped in thine.
That I might vex an army at one time,

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: I do repent me, hold,

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: You'll die the better christian then.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: I do confess I have wronged thee Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Confession is but poor amends for wrong,
Unless a rope would follow.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: I ask thee pardon.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I'm your hired whore fir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: I yield both purse and body.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Both are mine, and now at my disposing.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Spare my life.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I scorn to strike thee basely.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Spoken like a noble girl i'faith.
sp.p: Heart I think I fight with a familiar, or the ghost of a fencer, she's wounded me gallantly, call you this a lecherous voyage? Here's blood would have served me this seven year in broken heads and cut fingers, and it now runs all out together, pox a'the three pigeons, I would the coach were here now to carry me to the chirurgeons.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: If I could meet my enemies one by one thus,
I might make pretty shift with 'em in time,
And make 'em know, she that has wit, and spirit,
May scorn to live beholding to her body for meat,
Or for apparel like your common dame,
That makes shame get her clothes, to cover shame.
Base is that mind, that kneels unto her body,
As if a husband stood in awe on's wife,
My spirit shall be mistress of this house,
As long as I have time in't. — — o
Here comes my man that would be: 'tis his hour.
Faith a good well set fellow, if his spirit
Be answerable to his umbles; he walks stiff,
But whether he will stand to't stiffly, there's the point;
Has a good calf for't, and ye shall have many a woman
Choose him she means to meek her head, by his calf;
I do not know their tricks in't, faith he seems
A man without; I'll try what he is within,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: She told me Graies-inne fields twixt three and four,
I'll fit her mistress-ship with a piece of service,
I'm hired to rid the town of one mad girl.
What a pox ails you sir?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: He begins like a gentleman,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Heart, is the field so narrow, or your eyesight:
Life he comes back again.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Was this spoke to me sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I cannot tell sir.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Go you're a coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: You're a slave.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I hope there's law for you sir.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Ye, do you see sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Heart this is no good dealing, pray let me know what house your off.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: One of the temple sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Mass so methinks .

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: And yet sometime I lie about chick lane.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I like you the worse because you shift your lodging ▪
I'll not meddle with you for that trick sir. (So often

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: A good shift, but it shall not serve your turn.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: You'll give me leave to pass about my business sir.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Your business, I'll make you wait on me before I ha' done, and glad to serve me too.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: How sir, serve you, not if there were no more men in England.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: But if there were no more women in England
I hope you'd wait upon your mistress then,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: O your a tried spirit at a push sir,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: What would your worship have me do.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: You a fighter.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: No, I praise heaven, I had better grace and more manners.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: As how I pray sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Life, 'thad been a beastly part of me to have drawn my weapons upon my mistress, all the world would a cried
shame of me for that.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Why but you knew me not.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Do not say so mistress, I knew you by your wide straddle, as well as if I had been in your belly.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Well, we shall try you further, ith' mean time we give you entertainment.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Thank your good mistress-ship.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: How many suits have you.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: No more suits than backs mistress.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Well if you deserve, I cast of this, next week,
And you may creep into't.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Thank your good worship.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Come follow me to s. Thomas apostles,
I'll put a livery cloak upon your back, the first thing I do,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I follow my dear mistress.
sp.stage: Enter mistress Gallipot as from supper, her husband after her.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: What Pru, nay sweet prudence.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: What a pruing keep you, I think the baby would have a teat it kyes so, pray be not so fond of me, leave your city humours, I'm vexed at you to see how like a calf you come bleating after me.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: Nay honey Pru: how does your rising up before all the table show? and flinging from my friends so uncivilly, fie Pru, fie, come.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Then up and ride i'faith.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: Up and ride, nay my pretty Pru, that's far from my thought, duck: why mouse, thy mind is nibbling at something, what's is't, what lies upon thy stomach?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: Such an ass as you: hoyda, you're best turn midwife, or physician: you're a pothecary already, but I'm none of your drugs.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: Thou art a sweet drug, sweetest Pru, and the more thou art pounded, the more precious.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Must you be prying into a woman's secrets: say ye?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Woman's secrets.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: What? I cannot have a qualm come upon me but your teeth waters, till your nose hang over it.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: It is my love dear wife.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: Your love? your love is all words; give me deeds, I cannot abide a man that's too fond o'er me, so cookish; thou dost not know how to handle a woman in her kind,

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: No Pru? why I hope I have handled. —

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Handle a fool's head of your own, — fie — fie.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, 'tis such a wasp; it does me good now to have her sing me, little rogue.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: Now fie how you vex me, I cannot abide these apron husbands: such cotqueans, you overdo your things, they become you scurvily.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: Upon my life she breeds, heaven knows how I have strained myself to please her, night and day: I wonder why we citizens should get children so fretful and untoward in the breeding, their fathers being for the most part as gentle as milch kine: shall I leave thee my Pru.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: Thou shalt not be vexed no more, pretty kind rogue, take no cold sweet Pru.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: As your wit has done: now master Laxton show your head, what news from you? would any husband suspect that a woman crying, buy any scurvygrass, should bring love letters amongst her herbs to his wife, pretty trick, fine conveyance? had jealousy a thousand eyes, a silly woman with scurvygrass blinds them all; Laxton with bays crown I thy wit for this, it deserves praise.
sp.l: This makes me affect thee more, this proves thee wise,
Lack what poor shift is love forced to devise? (Toth' point)
sp.stage:
She reads the letter. O sweet creature — (A sweet beginning) pardon my long absence, for thou shalt shortly be possessed with my presence; though Demophon was false to Phillis, I will be to thee as Pan-da-rus was to Cressida: though Eneus made an ass of Dido, I will die to thee ere I do so; oh sweetest creature make much of me, for no man
beneath the silver moon shall make more of a woman then I do of thee, furnish me therefore with thirty pounds, you must do it of necessity for me; I languish till I see some comfort come from thee, protesting not to die in thy debt, but rather to live so, as hitherto I have and will. Thy true Laxton ever.
sp.l: Alas poor gentleman, troth I pity him,
How shall I raise this money? thirty pound?
'Tis thirty sure, a 3 before an 0,
I know his threes too well; my childbed linen?
Shall I pawn that for him? then if my mark
Be known I am undone; it may be thought
My husband's bankrupt: which way shall I turn?
Laxton, what with my own fears, and thy wants,
I'm 〈◊〉 needle twixt two adamants.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: Nay, nay, wife, the women are all up, ha, how, reading a letters? I smell a goose, a couple of capons, and a gammon of bacon from her mother out of the country, I hold my life, — steal, — steal.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: O beshrew your heart.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: What letter's that? I'll see't.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: O would thou hadst no eyes to see the downfall of me and thyself: I'm for ever, for ever I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: What ails my Pru? what paper's that thou tearest?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Would I could tear
My very heart in pieces: for my soul
Lies on the rack of shame, that tortures me
Beyond a woman's suffering.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gall:
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: Had you no other vengeance to throw down,
But even in height of all my joys?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Dear woman.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: When the full sea of pleasure and content seemed to flow over me.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p:
As thou desirest to keep me out of bedlam,
tell what troubles thee, is not thy child at nurse fallen sick, or dead?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: O no.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Heavens bless me, are my barns and houses
Yonder at Hockly hole consumed with fire,
I can build more, sweet Pru.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: 'Tis worse, 'tis worse.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: My factor broke, or is the Jonas sunk.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Would all we had were swallowed in the waves,
Rather than both should be the scorn of slaves.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: I'm at my wit's end.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: O my dear husband,
Where once I thought myself a fixed star,
Placed only in the heaven of thine arms,
I fear now I shall prove a wanderer,
O Laxton, Laxton, is it then my fate
To be by thee o'erthrown?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Defend me wisdom,
From falling into frenzy, on my knees. (Thy bosom.
Sweet Pru, speak, what's that Laxton who so heavy lies on

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: I shall sure run mad.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: I shall run mad for company then: speak to me,
I'm Gallipot thy husband, — Pru, — why Pru.
Art sick in conscience for some villainous deed
Thou wert about to act, didst mean to rob me,
Tush I forgive thee, hast thou on my bed
Thrust my soft pillow under another's head?
I'll wink at all faults Pru, 'las that's no more,
Then what some neighbours near thee, have done before,
Sweet honey Pru, what's that Laxton?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Out with him.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: O he's born to be my undoer,
This hand which thou callest thine, to him was given,
To him was I made sure ith' sight of heaven.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: I never heard this thunder.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: Yes, yes, before
I was to thee contracted, to him I swore,
Since last I saw him twelve months three times told,
The moon hath drawn through her light silver bow,
For o'er the seas he went, and it was said,
(But rumor lies) that he in France was dead.
But he's alive, o he's alive, he sent,
That letter to me, which in rage I rent,
Swearing with oaths most damnably to have me,
Or tear me from this bosom, o heavens save me,

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: My heart will break, — shamed and undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: So black a day (Poor wretch) went o'er thee never.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: If thou shouldst wrestle with him at the law,
Thou'rt sure to fall, no odd slight, no prevention.
I'll tell him thou'rt with child.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Umh.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gall.
sp.p: Or give out one of my men was ta'en a-bed with thee.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Umh, umh.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Before I lose thee my dear Pru;
I'll drive it to that push.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Worse, and worse still,
You embrace a mischief, to prevent an ill.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: I'll buy thee of him, stop his mouth with gold,
Thinkest thou 'twill do.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: O me, heavens grant it would,
Yet now my senses are set more in tune,
He writ, as I remember in his letter,
That he in riding up and down had spent,
(Ere he could find me) thirty pounds, send that,
Stand not on thirty with him.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: Forty Pru, say thou the word 'tis done, we venture lives for wealth, but must do more to keep our wives, thirty or forty Pru.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Thirty good sweet
Of an ill bargain let's save what we can,
I'll pay it him with my tears, he was a man
when first I knew him of a meek spirit,
All goodness is not yet dried up I hope.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gall.
sp.l: He shall have thirty pound, let that stop all:
Loves sweets taste best, when we have drunk down gall.
sp.stage: Enter master Tiltyard, and his wife, master goshawk, and mistress Openworke.
sp.l: God's so, our friends; come, come, smooth your cheek;
After a storm the face of heaven looks sleek.

sp.speaker: Maist. Tilt.
sp.l: Did I not tell you these turtles were together?

sp.speaker: Mistress Tilt.
sp.l: How dost thou sirrah? why sister Gallipot?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Lord how she's changed?

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Is your wife ill sir?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Yes indeed la sir, very ill, very ill, never worse,

sp.speaker: Mistress Tilt.
sp.l: How her head burns, feel how her pulses work.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Sister lie down a little, that always does me good.

sp.speaker: Mistress Tilt.
sp.l: In good sadness I find best ease in that too,
Has she laid some hot thing to her stomach?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: No, but I will lay something anon.

sp.speaker: Maist. Tilt.
sp.p: Come, come fools, you trouble her, shall's go master goshawk?

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: Yes sweet master Tiltyard; sirrah Rosamond I hold my life Gallipot hath vexed his wife.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: She has a horrible high colour indeed.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: We shall have your face painted with the same red soon at night, when your husband comes from his rubbers in a false alley; thou wilt not believe me that his bowls run with a wrong bias.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: It cannot sink into me, that he feeds upon stale mutton abroad, having better and fresher at home.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: What if I bring thee, where thou shalt see him stand at rack and manger?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: I'll saddle him in's kind, and spur him till he kick again.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Shall thou and I ride our journey then.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: No more; come master Tiltyard, shall we leap into the stirrups with our women, and amble home?

sp.speaker: Maist. Tilt.
sp.l: Yes, yes, come wife.

sp.speaker: Mistress Tilt.
