sp.l: Introth sister, I hope you will do well for all this.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: I hope I shall: farewell good sister: sweet master goshawk.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Welcome brother, most kindly welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Thanks sir for our good cheer.
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Gallipot and his wife.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: It shall be so, because a crafty knave
Shall not out reach me, nor walk by my door
With my wife arm in arm, as 'twere his whore,
I'll give him a golden coxcomb, thirty pound:
Tush Pru what's thirty pound? sweet duck look cheerly.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Thou art worthy of my heart thou buy'st it dear.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: Uds light the tide's against me, a pox of your apothecaryship: o for some glister to set him going; 'tis one of Hercules' labours, to tread one of these city hens, because their cocks are still crowing over them; there's no turning tale here, I must on.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: O, husband see he comes.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Let me deal with him.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Bless you sir.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Be you blessed too sir if you come in peace.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Have you any good pudding tobacco sir?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: O pick no quarrels gentle sir, my husband
Is not a man of weapon, as you are,
He knows all, I have opened all before him, concerning you.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Zounds has she shown my letters.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gal.
sp.l: Suppose my case were yours, what would you do.
At such a pinch, such batteries, such assaults ▪
Of father, mother, kindred, to dissolve
The knot you tied, and to be bound to him?
How could you shift this storm off?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: If I know hang me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Besides a story of your death was read
Each minute to me.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: What a pox means this riddling?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Be wise sir, let not you and I be tossed
On lawyer's pens; they have sharp nibs and draw
Men's very heart blood from them; what need you sir
To beat the drum of my wife's infamy,
And call your friends together sir to prove
Your precontact, when she's confessed it?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Umh sir, — has she confessed it?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: She's i'faith to me sir, upon your letter sending.

sp.speaker: M. is't. Gal.
sp.l: I have, I have.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: If I let this iron cool call me slave,
Do you hear, you dame prudence? think'st thou vile woman
I'll take these blows and wink?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Upon my knees.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Out impudence.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: You goatish slaves,
No wild foul to cut up but mine?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Alas sir,
You make her flesh to tremble, fright her not,
She shall do reason, and what's fit.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: I'll have thee, wert thou more common
Than an hospital, and more diseased. —

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: But one word good sir.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: I married her, have line with her, and got
Two children on her body, think but on that;
Have you so beggarly an appetite
When I upon a dainty dish have fed
To dine upon my scraps, my leavings? ha sir?
Do I come near you vow sir?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Be lady you touch me.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Would not you scorn to wear my clothes sir?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Right sir.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Then pray sir wear not her, for she's a garment
So fitting for my body, I'm loath
Another should put it on, you will undo both.
Your letter (As she said) complained you had spent
In quest of her, some thirty pound, I'll pay it;
Shall that sir stop this gap up twixt you two?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Well if I swallow this wrong, let her thank you:
The money being paid sir, I am gone:
Farewell, o women happy's he trusts none.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: Dispatch him hence sweet husband.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Yes dear wife: pray sir come in, ere master
Thou shalt in wine drink to him,
sp.stage: Exit master Gallipot and his wife. (Laxton part

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: With all my heart; — how dost thou like my wit?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Rarely, that wile
By which the serpent did the first woman beguile,
Did ever since, all women's bosoms fill;
You're apple eaters all, deceivers still.
sp.stage: Enter sir Alexander Wengraue: sir Davy dapper, sir Adam Appleton, at one door, and Trapdore at another door.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Out with your tale sir Davy, to sir Adam.
A knave is in mine eye deep in my debt.

sp.speaker: Sir Da.
sp.l: Nay: if he be a knave sir, hold him fast.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Speak softly, what egg is there hatching now.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: A duck's egg sir, a duck that has eaten a frog, I have cracked the shell, and some villainy or other will peep out presently; the duck that sits is the bouncing ramp (That roaring girl my mistress) the drake that must tread is your son Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Be quick.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: As the tongue of an oyster wench.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And see thy news be true.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: As a barber's every Saturday night — mad Moll.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ah.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Must be let in without knocking at your back gate.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Your chamber will be made bawdy.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: She comes in a shirt of male.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: How shirt of male?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Yes sir or a male shirt, that's to say in man's apparel.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: To my son.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Close to your son: your son and her moon will be in conjunction, if all alminacks lie not, her black safeguard is turned into a deep slop, the holes of her upper body to button holes, her waistcoat to a doublet, her placket to the ancient seat of a codpiece, and you shall take 'em both with standing collars.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Art sure of this?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: As every throng is sure of a pickpocket, as sure as a whore is of the clients all Michaelmas term, and of the pox after the term.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The time of their tilting?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Three.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The day?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: This.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Away ply it, watch her.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: As the devil doth for the death of a bawd, I'll watch her, do you catch her.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: She's fast: here weave thou the nets; hark,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: They are made. (Maintain't.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I told them thou didst owe me money; hold it up:

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Stiffly; as a Puritan does contention,
Fox I owe thee not the value of a halfpenny halter.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Thou shalt be hanged in't ere thou scape so.
Varlet I'll make thee look through a grate.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I'll do't presently, through a tavern grate, drawer: pish.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Has the knave vexed you sir?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Asked him my money,
He swears my son received it: o that boy
will ne'er leave heaping sorrows on my heart,
Till he has broke it quite.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Is he still wild?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: As is a Russian bear.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: But he has left
His old haunt with that baggage.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Worse still and worse,
He lays on me his shame, I on him my curse.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: My son Jack dapper then shall run with him,
All in one pasture.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Proves your son bade too sir?

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: As villainy can make him: your Sebastian
Doors but on one drab, mine on a thousand,
A noise of fiddlers, tobacco, wine and a whore,
A mercer that will let him take up more,
Dice, and a water spaniel with a duck: o,
Bring him a-bed with these, when his purse jingles,
Roaring boys follow at's tale, fencers and ningles,
(Beasts Adam never gave name to) these horseleeches suck
My son, he being drawn dry, they all live on smoke.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Tobacco?

sp.speaker: S. Davy
sp.l: Right, but I have in my brain
A windmill going that shall grind to dust
The follies of my son, and make him wise,
Or a stark fool; pray lend me your advice.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: That shall you good sir Davy.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: Here's the springe
I ha' set to catch this woodcock in: an action
In a false name (Unknown to him) is entered.
I'th counter to arrest Jack dapper.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: Think you the counter cannot break him?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Break him?
Yes and break's heart too if he lie there long.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: I'll make him sing a counter tenor sure.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: No way to tame him like it, there he shall learn
What money is indeed, and how to spend it.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: He's bridled there.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ay, yet knows not how to mend it,
Bedlam cures not more madmen in a year,
Than one of the counters does, men pay more dear
There for there wit then anywhere ; a counter
Why 'tis an university, who not sees?
As scholars there, so here men take degrees,
And follow the same studies (All alike.)
Scholars learn first logic and rhetoric.
So does a prisoner; with fine honeyed speech
At's first coming in he doth persuade, beseech,
He may be lodged with one that is not itchy;
To lie in a clean chamber, in sheets not lousy,
But when he has no money, then does he try,
By subtle logic, and quaint sophistry,
To make the keepers trust him.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Say they do.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Then he's a graduate.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: Say they trust him not,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Then is he held a freshman and a sot,
And never shall commence, but being still barred
Be expulsed from the master's side, toth' twopenny ward,
Or else i'th hole, beg placed.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: When then I pray proceeds a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: When money being the theme,
He can dispute with his hard creditors hearts,
And get out clear, he's then a master of arts;
Sir Davy send your son to Woodstreet college,
A gentleman can nowhere get more knowledge.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: There gallants study hard.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: True: to get money.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: 'Lies byth' heels i'faith, thanks, thanks, I ha' sent
For a couple of bears shall paw him.
sp.stage: Enter seriant Curtilax and Yeoman Hanger.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Who comes yonder?

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: They look like puttocks, these should be they.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I know 'em, they are officers, sir we'll leave you.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: My good knights.
Leave me, you see I'm haunted now with spirits.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: This old muzzle chops should be he
By the fellow's description: save you sir.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.p: Come hither you mad varlets, did not my man tell you I watched here for you.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: One in a blue coat sir told us, that in this place an old gentleman would watch us for, a thing contrary to our oath, for we are to watch for every wicked member in a city.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.p: You'll watch then for ten thousand, what's thy name honesty?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Sergeant Curtilax I sir.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: An excellent name for a sergeant, Curtilax.
Sergeants indeed are weapons of the law,
When prodigal ruffians far in debt are grown,
Should not you cut them; citizens were o'erthrown,
Thou dwellest hereby in Holborn Curtilax.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: That's my circuit sir, I conjure most in that circle.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: And what young towards whelp is this?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: Of the same litter, his yeoman sir, my name's hanger.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: Yeoman Hanger.
One pair of shears sure cut out both your coats,
You have two names most dangerous to men's throats,
You two are villainous loads on gentlemen's backs,
Dear ware, this hanger and this Curtilax.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: We are as other men are sir, I cannot see but he who makes a show of honesty and religion, if his claws can fasten to his liking, he draws blood; all that live in the world, are but great fish and little fish, and feed upon one another, some eat up whole men, a sergeant cares but for the shoulder of a man, they call us knaves and curs, but many times he that sets us on, worries more lambs one year, than we do in seven.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: Spoken like a noble Cerberus, is the action entered?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: His name is entered in the book of unbelievers.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: What book's that?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: The book where all prisoners names stand, and not one amongst forty, when he comes in, believes to come out in haste.

sp.speaker: S. Da.
sp.l: Be as dogged to him as your office allows you to be.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: O sir.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: You know the unthrift Jack dapper.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Ay, ay, sir, that gull? as well as I know my yeoman.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.l: And you know his father too, sir Davy dapper?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: As damned a usurer as ever was among Jews; if he were sure his father's skin would yield him any money, he would when he dies flay it off, and sell it to cover drums for children at Bartholmew fair.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.p: What toads are these to spit poison on a man to his face? do you see (My honest rascals?) yonder greyhound is the dog he hunts with, out of that tavern Jack dapper will sally sa, sa; give the counter, on, set upon him.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We'll charge him upo'the back sir.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.p: Take no bail, put mace enough into his caudle, double your files, traverse your ground.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Brave sir.

sp.speaker: S. Davy:
sp.l: Cry arm, arm, arm.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Thus sir.

sp.speaker: S. Davy.
sp.p: There boy, there boy, away: look to your prey my true English wolves, and and so I vanish.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Some warden of the sergeants begat this old fellow upon my life, stand close.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: Shall the ambuscado lie in one place?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: No uooke thou yonder.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Ralph.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: What says my brave captain male and female?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: This Holborn is such a wrangling street,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: That's because lawyer's walks to and fro in't.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Here's such justling, as if every one we met were drunk and reeled.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Stand mistress do you not smell carrion?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Carrion? no, yet I spy ravens.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Some poor wind-shaken gallant will anon fall into sore labour, and these men-midwives must bring him to bed i'the counter, there all those that are great with child with debts, lie in.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Stand up.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Like your new maypole.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: Whist, whew.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Hump, no.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Peeping? it shall go hard huntsmen, but I'll spoil your game, they look for all the world like two infected maltmen coming muffled up in their cloaks in a frosty morning to London.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: A course, captain; a bear comes to the stake.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: It should be so, for the dogs struggle to be let loose.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.l: Whew.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Hemp.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Hark Trapdore, follow your leader.

sp.speaker: Jack Dap.
sp.l: Gul.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.l: Master.

sp.speaker: Jack Dap.
sp.l: Didst ever see such an ass as I am boy?

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: No by my troth sir, to lose all your money, yet have false dice of your own, why 'tis as I saw a great fellow used tother day, he had a fair sword and buckler, and yet a butcher dry beat him with a cudgel.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Honest sergeant fly, fly master dapper you'll be arrested else.

sp.speaker: Jack Dap.
sp.l: Run Gul and draw.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.l: Run master, gull follows you.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I know you well enough, you're but a whore to hang upon any man.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Whores then are like sergeants, so now hang you, draw rogue, but strike not: for a broken pate they'll keep their beds, and recover twenty marks damages.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: You shall pay for this rescue, run down shoelane and meet him.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Shu, is this a rescue gentlemen or no?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Rescue? A pox on 'em, Trapdore let's away,
I'm glad I have done perfect one good work today,
If any gentleman be in scriveners bands,
Send but for Moll, she'll bail him by these hands.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Unhappy in the follies of a son,
Led against judgement, sense, obedience,
And all the powers of nobleness and wit;
O wretched father, now Trapdore will she come?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: In man's apparel sir, I am in her heart now,
And share in all her secrets.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Peace, peace, peace.
Here take my German watch, hang't up in sight,
That I may see her hang in English for't.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I warrant you for that now, next sessions rids her sir,
This watch will bring her in better than a hundred constables.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Good Trapdore sayest thou so, thou cheerest my heart
After a storm of sorrow, — my gold chain too,
Here take a hundred marks in yellow links.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: That will do well to bring the watch to light sir.
And worth a thousand of your headborowes lanterns.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Place that a'the court cubbart, let it lie
Full in the view of her thief-whorish eye.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: She cannot miss it sir, I see't so plain, that I could steal't myself.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Perhaps thou shalt too,
That or something as weighty; what she leaves,
Thou shalt come closely in, and filch away,
And all the weight upon her back I'll lay.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: You cannot assure that sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No, what lets it?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Being a stout girl, perhaps she'll desire pressing,
Than all the weight must lie upon her belly.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Belly or back I care not so I've one.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: You're of my mind for that sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Hang up my ruff band with the diamond at it,
It may be she'll like that best.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: It's well for her, that she must have her choice, he thinks nothing too good for her, if you hold on this mind a little longer, it shall be the first work I do to turn thief myself; would do a man good to be hanged when he is so well provided for.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: So, well said; all hangs well, would she hung so too,
The sight would please me more, than all their gilsterings:
O that my mysteries to such straits should run,
That I must rob myself to bless my son.
sp.stage: Enter Sebastian, with Marry Fitz-allard like a page, and Mol.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou hast done me a kind office, without touch
Either of sin or shame, our loves are honest.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I'd scorn to make such shift to bring you together else ▪

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Now have I time and opportunity
Without all fear to bid thee welcome love.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Never with more desire and harder venture.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: How strange this shows one man to kiss another.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'd kiss such men to choose Moll,
Methinks a woman's lip tastes well in a doublet:

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Many an old madam has the better fortune then,
Whose breathes grew stale before the fashion came,
If that will help 'em, as you think 'twill do,
They'll learn in time to pluck on the hose too.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The older they wax Moll, troth I speak seriously,
As some have a conceit their drink tastes better
In an outlandish cup then in our own,
So methinks every kiss she gives me now
In this strange form, is worth a pair of two,
Here we are safe, and furthest from the eye
Of all suspicion, this is my father's chamber,
Upon which floor he never steps till night.
Here he mistrusts me not, nor I his coming,
at mine own chamber he still pries unto me,
My freedom is not there at mine own finding,
Still checked and curbed, here he shall miss his purpose.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: And what's your business now, you have your mind sir;
At your great suit I promised you to come,
I pitied her for name's sake, that a Moll
Should be so crossed in love, when there's so many,
That owes nine lays a piece, and not so little:
My tailor fitted her, how like you his work?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: So well, no art can mend it, for this purpose,
But to thy wit and help we're chief in debt,
And must live still beholding.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Any honest pity
I'm willing to bestow upon poor ringdoves.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'll offer no worse play.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Nay and you should sir,
I should draw first and prove the quicker man,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hold, there shall need no weapon at this meeting,
But cause thou shalt not lose thy fury idle,
Here take this vial, run upon the guts,
And end thy quarrel singing.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Like a swan above bridge,
For look you here's the bridge, and here am I.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hold on sweet Moll.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I've heard her much commended sir, for one that was ne'er taught.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: I'm much beholding to 'em, well since you'll needs put us together sir, I'll play my part as well as I can; it shall ne'er be said I came into a gentleman's chamber, and let his instrument hang by the walls.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Why well said Moll i'faith, it had been a shame for that gentleman then, that would have let it hung still, and ne'er offered thee it.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: There it should have been still then for Moll, for though the world judge impudently of me, I ne'er came into that chamber yet, where I took down the instrument myself.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
Pish let 'em prate abroad, thou'rt here where thou art
known and loved, there be a thousand close dames that will call the vial an unmannerly instrument for a woman, and therefore talk broadly of thee, when you shall have them sit wider to a worse quality.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Push, I ever fall asleep and think not of 'em sir, and thus I dream.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Prithee let's hear thy dream Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I dream there is a mistress,
And she lays out the money,
She goes unto her sisters,
She never comes at any.
sp.stage: Enter sir Alexander behind them she says she went to'th burse for patterns, you shall find her at saint katherns, and comes home with never a penny.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: That's a free mistress 'Faith.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ay, ay, ay, like her that sings it, one of thine own choosing.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: But shall I dream again?
Here comes a wench will brave ye,
Her courage was so great,
She lay with one o'the navy,
Her husband lying i'the fleet.
Yet oft with him she cavilled,
I wonder what she ails,
Her husband's ship lay gravelled,
When hers could hoist up sails,
Yet she began like all my foes,
To call whore first: for so do those;
A pox of all false tails.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Marry amen say I.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: So say I too.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Hang up the vial now sir: all this while I was in a dream, one shall lie rudely then; but being awake, I keep my legs together; a watch, what's o'clock here.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Now, now, she's trapped.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Between one and two; nay then I care not: a watch and a musician are cousin germanes in one thing, they must both keep time well, or there's no goodness in 'em, the one else deserves to be dashed against a wall, and tother to have his brains knocked out with a fiddle case, what? A loose chain and a dangling diamond.
sp.l: Here were a brave booty for an evening-thief now,
There's many a younger brother would be glad
To look twice in at a window for't,
And wriggle in and out, like an eel in a sandbag,
O if men's secret youthful faults should judge 'em,
'T would be the generalest execution,
sp.p: That ere was seen in England; there would be but few left to sing the ballets, there would be so much work: most of our brokers would be chosen for hangmen, a good day for them: they might renew their wardrobes of free cost then.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This is the roaring wench must do us good.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: No poison sir but serves us for some use, which is confirmed in her.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Peace, peace, foot I did here him sure, where ere he be.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Who did you hear?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: My father, 'twas like a sight of his, I must be wary,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No wilt not be, am I alone so wretched
That nothing takes? I'll put him to his plunge for't.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Life, here he comes, — sir I beseech you take it,
Your way of teaching does so much content me,
I'll make it four pound, here's forty shillings sir.
I think I name it right: help me good Moll,
Forty in hand.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Sir you shall pardon me,
I have more of the meanest scholar I can teach,
This pays me more, than you have offered yet.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: At the next quarter
When I receive the means my father ''lows me.
You shall have tother forty,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: This were well now,
Were't to a man, whose sorrows had blind eyes,
but mine behold his follies and untruths,
With two clear glasses — how now?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: What's he there?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You're come in good time sir, I've a suit to you,
I'd crave your present kindness.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: What is he there?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A gentleman, a musician sir, one of excellent fingering ▪

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ay, I think so, I wonder how they scaped her.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Has the most delicate stroke sir,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: A stroke indeed, I feel it at my heart,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Puts down all your famous musicians.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ay, a whore may put down a hundred of 'em.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Forty shillings is the agreement sir between us,
Now sir, my present means, mounts but to half on't.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And he stands upon the whole.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I indeed does he sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And will do still, he'll ne'er be in other tail,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Therefore I'd stop his mouth sir, and I could,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Hum true, there is no other way indeed,
His folly hardens, shame must needs succeed.
Now sir I understand you profess music.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I am a poor servant to that liberal science sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Where is it you teach?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Right against Clifford's inn.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Hum that's a fit place for it: you have many scholars.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: And some of worth, whom I may call my masters.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I true, a company of whoremasters; you teach to sing too?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Marry do I sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I think you'll find an apt scholar of my son, especially for pricksong.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I have much hope of him.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I am sorry for't, I have the less for that: you can play any lesson.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: At first sight sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: There's a thing called the witch, can you play that?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I would be sorry any one should mend me in't.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ay, I believe thee, thou hast so bewitched my son,
No care will mend the work that thou hast done,
I have bethought myself since my art fails,
I'll make her policy the art to trap her.
Here are four angels marked with holes in them
Fit for his cracked companions, gold he will give her,
These will I make induction to her ruin,
And rid shame from my house, grief from my heart
Here son, in what you take content and pleasure,
Want shall not curb you, pay the gentleman
His latter half in gold.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O may the operation an't, end three,
In her, life: shame, in him; and grief, in me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Faith thou shalt have 'em 'tis my father's gift,
Never was man beguiled with better shift.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: He that can take me for a male musician,
I cannot choose but make him my instrument,
And play upon him.
sp.stage: Enter mistress Gallipot, and mistress Openworke.

sp.speaker: Mi Gal.
sp.l: Is then that bird of yours (Master goshawk) so wild?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: A goshawk, a puttock; all for prey: he angles for fish, but he loves flesh better.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: Is't possible his smooth face should have wrinkles in't, and we not see them?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Possible? why have not many handsome legs in silk stockings villainous splay feet for all their great roses?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Troth sirrah thou sayest true.

sp.speaker: Mistress Op.
sp.p: Didst never see an archer (As thou'st walked by bun-hill) look a squint when he drew his bow?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: Yes, when his arrows have flin'e towards Islington, his eyes have shot clean contrary towards Pimlico.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: For all the world so does master goshawk double with me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: O fie upon him, if he double once he's not for me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Because goshawk go ▪ in a shag-ruff band, with a face sticking up in't, which shows like an agate set in acrampe ring, he thinks I'm in love with him.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Alas I think he takes his mark amiss in thee.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: He has by often beating into me made me believe that my husband kept a whore.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Swore to me that my husband this very morning went in a boat with a tilt over it, to the three pigeons at Brainford, and his punk with him under his tilt.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: That were wholesome.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: I believed it, fell a swearing at him, cursing of harlots, made me ready to hoist up sail, and be there as soon as he.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: And for that voyage goshawk comes hither incontinently, but sirrah this water-spaniel dives after no duck but me, his hope is having me at Brainford to make me cry quack.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: Art sure of it?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Sure of it? my poor innocent Openwork came in as I was poking my ruff, presently hit I him i'the teeth with the three pigeons: he forswore all, I up and opened all, and now stands he (In a shop hard by) like a musket on a rest, to hit goshawk i'the eye, when he comes to fetch me to the boat.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: Such another lame gelding offered to carry me through thick and thin, (Laxton sirrah) but I am rid of him now.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Happy is the woman can be rid of 'em all; alas what are your whisking gallants to our husbands, weigh 'emrightly man for man.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: Troth mere shallow things.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Idle simple things, running heads, and yet let 'emrun over us never so fast, we shopkeepers (When all's done) are sure to have 'em in our pursnets at length, and when they are in, lord what simple animals they are.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Then they hang head.

sp.speaker: Most. Gal.
sp.l: Then they droop.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Then they write letters.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Then they cog.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Then they deal under hand with us, and we must ingle with our husbands a-bed , and we must swear they are our cousins, and able to do us a pleasure at court.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: And yet when we have done our best, all's but put into a riven dish, we are but frumped at and libelled upon.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: O if it were the good lords will, there were a law made, no citizen should trust any of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Hush sirrah, goshawk flutters.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: How now, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Nay are you ready? A little thing you see makes us ready.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Us? why, must she make one i'the voyage?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: O by any means, do I know how my husband will handle me?

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: 'foot, how shall I find water, to keep these two mills going? Well since you'll needs be clapped under hatches, if I sail not with you both till all split, hang me up at the main yard, and duck me; it's but lickering them both soundly, and then you shall see their cork heels fly up high, like two swans when their tails are above water, and their long necks under water, diving to catch gudgeons: come, come, oars stand ready, the tide's with us, on with those false faces, blow winds and thou shalt take thy husband, casting out his net to catch fresh salmon at Brainford.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: I believe you'll eat of a cod's head of your own dressing, before you reach half way thither.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: So, so, follow close, pin as you go.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Do you hear?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Yes, I thank my ears.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: I must have a bout with your pothecaryship,

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: At what weapon?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: I must speak with you.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Lax
sp.l: No? you shall.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Shall? away soused sturgeon, half fish, half flesh.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: I'faith gib, are you spitting, I'll cut your tail puss-cat for this,

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: Alas poor Laxton, I think thy tail's cut already: your worst;

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: If I do not, —

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Come, ha'you done?
Sfoot Rosamond, your husband. welcome,

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: How now? sweet mayst goshawk, none more
I have wanted your embracements: when friends meet,
The music of the spheres sounds not more sweet,
Then does their conference: who is this? Rosamond:
Wife: how now sister?

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Silence if you love me.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Why masked?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Does a mask grieve you sir?

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: It does.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Then you're best get you a mumming.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: S'foot you'll spoil all.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: May not we cover our bare faces with masks
As well as you cover your bald heads with hats?

sp.speaker: Ma. Op.
sp.l: No masks, why, they're thieves to beauty, that rob
Of admiration in which true love lies, (Eyes
Why are masks worn? why good? or why desired?
Unless by their gay covers wits are fired
To read the vildest looks; many bad faces,
(Because rich gems are treasured up in cases)
Pass by their privilege currant, but as caves
Damn miser's gold, so masks are beauty's graves,
Men never meet women with such muffled eyes,
But they curse her, that first did masks devise,
And swear it was some beldame. Come off with't.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Good faces masked are jewels kept by spirits.
Hide none but bad ones, for they poison men's sights,
show then as shopkeepers do their broidred stuff,
(By owl light) fine wares cannot be open enough,
Prithee (Sweet rose) come strike this sail.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Sail? (Eyes:

sp.speaker: Maist. Op.
sp.l: Ha? yes wife strike sail, for storms are in thine

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: They're here sir in my brows if any rise.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Ha brows? (What says she friend) pray tell me
Your two flags were advanced; the comedy, (Why
Come what's the comedy?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Westward ho.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: 'Tis westward ho she says.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Are you both mad?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Is't market day at Brainford, and your ware not sent up yet?

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: What market day? what ware?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Apy with three pigeons in't, 'tis drawn and stays your cutting up.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: As you regard my credit.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Art mad?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Yes lecherous goat; baboon.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Baboon? then toss me in a blanket,

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Do I it well?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: Rarely.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Belike sir she's not well; best leave her.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: No,
I'll stand the storm now how fierce soe'er it blow.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Did I for this lose all my friends? refuse
Rich hopes, and golden fortunes, to be made
A stale to a common whore?

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: This does amaze me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: O God, o God, feed at reversion now?
A strumpets leaving?

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Rosamond,

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: I sweat, would I lay in cold harbour.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Thou hast struck ten thousand daggers through my heart.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Not I by heaven sweet wife. (Thee

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Go devil go; that which thou swearest by, damns

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: S'heart will you undo me?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: Why stay you here? the star, by which you sail, shines yonder above Chelsy; you lose your shore if this moon light you: seek out your light whore.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Push; your western pug.

sp.speaker: Gosh,
sp.l: Zounds now hell roars.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.p: With whom you tilted in a pair of oars, this very morning.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Oars?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: At Brainford sir.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.p: Rack not my patience: master goshawk, some slave has buzzed this into her, has he not? I run a tilt in Brainford with a woman? 'tis a lie: what old bawd tells thee this? 'sdeath 'tis a lie.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: 'Tis one to thy face shall justify all that I speak.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Ud'soul do but name that rascal.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: No sir I will not.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Keep thee there girl: — then!

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Sister know you this varlet?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Swear true,
sp.p: Is there a rogue so low damned? A second Judas? A common hangman? cutting a man's throat? does it to his face? bite me behind my back? A cur dog? swear if you know this hellhound.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: In truth I do,

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: His name?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: Not for the world;
To have you to stab him.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: O brave girls: worth gold.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: A word honest master goshawk.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: What do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.p: Keep off, and if the devil can give a name to this new fury, holla it throng my ear, or wrap it up in some hid character: I'll ride to Oxford, and watch out mine eyes, but I'll hear the brazen head speak: or else show me but one hair of his head or beard, that I may sample it; if the fiend I meet (In mine own house) I'll kill him: — the street.
sp.l: Or at the church door: — there — (Cause he seeks to untie
The knot God fastens) he deserves most to die.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: My husband titles him.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Master goshawk, pray sir
Swear to me, that you know him or know him not, (Wives,
Who makes me at Brainford to take up a petticoat beside my

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: By heaven that man I know not.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Come, come, you lie.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Will you not have all out?
By heaven I know no man beneath the moon
Should do you wrong, but if I had his name,
I'd print it in text letters.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Print thine own then,
Didst not thou swear to me he kept his whore?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: And that in sinful Brainford they would commit
That which our lips did water at sir, — ha?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Thou spider, that hast woven thy cunning web
In mine own house t'insnare me: hast not thou
Sucked nourishment even underneath this roof,
And turned it all to poison? spitting it,
On thy friend's face (My husband?) he as 'twere sleeping:
Only to leave him ugly to mine eyes,
That they might glance on thee.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Speak, are these lies?

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Mine own shame me confounds:

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: No more, he's stung;
Who'd think that in one body there could dwell
Deformity and beauty, (Heaven and hell)
Goodness I see is but outside, we all set,
In rings of gold, stones that be counterfeit:
I thought you none.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Pardon me.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Truth I do.
This blemish grows in nature not in you,
For man's creation stick even moles in scorn
On fairest cheeks, wife nothing is perfect born.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: I thought you had been born perfect.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: What's this whole world but a gilt rotten pill?
For at the heart lies the old chore still.
I'll tell you master goshawk, I in your eye
I have seen wanton fire, and then to try
The soundness of my judgement, I told you
I kept a whore, made you believe 'twas true,
Only to feel how your pulse beat, but find,
The world can hardly yield a perfect friend.
Come, come, a trick of youth, and 'tis forgiven,
This rub put by, our love shall run more even.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open,
sp.l: You'll deal upon men's wives no more?

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: No: — you teach me a trick for that.

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: Troth do not, they'll o'erreach thee.

sp.speaker: Mai. Open.
sp.l: Make my house yours sir still.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: I say you shall:
Seeing (Thus besieged) it holds out, 'twill never fall.
sp.stage: Enter master Gallipot, and Greenwit like a somner, Laxton muffled a loofo off.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gall.
sp.l: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: You sir? I have gone snaffling up and down by your door this hour to watch for you.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: What's the matter husband?

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: — I have caught a cold in my head sir, by sitting up late in the rose tavern, but I hope you understand my speech.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: I cite you by the name of Hippocrates Gallipot, and you by the name of prudence Gallipot, to appear upon Crastino, do you see, Crastino sancti dunstani (This easter term) in bow church.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gall.
sp.l: Where sir? what says he?

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: Bow: bow church, to answer to a libel of precontract on the part and behalf of the said prudence and another; you're best sir take a copy of the citation, 'tis but twelvepence.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: A citation?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: You pocky-nosed rascal, what slave fees you to this?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Slave? I ha' nothing to do with you, do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Laxton is't not? — what fagary is this?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: Trust me I thought sir this storm long ago had been full laid, when (If you be remembered) I paid you the last fifteen pound, besides the thirty you had first, — for then you swore.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Tush, tush sir, oaths,
Truth yet I'm loath to vex you, — tell you what;
Make up the money I had an hundred pound,
And take your belly full of her.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gall.
sp.l: An hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: What a 100 pound? he gets none: what a 100 pound?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Sweet Pru be calm, the gentleman offers thus,
If I will make the moneys that are passed
A 100 pound, he will discharge all courts,
And give his bond never to vex us more.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: A 100 pound? Alas; take sir but threescore,
Do you seek my undoing?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.p: I'll not bate one sixpence, — I'll maul you puss for spitting.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: Do thy worst,
Will fourscore stop thy mouth?

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: You're a slave,
Thou cheat, I'll now tear money from thy throat,
Husband lay hold on yonder tawnycoat.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: Nay gentlemen, seeing your women are so hot, I must lose my hair in their company I see.

sp.speaker: Mistress open
sp.p: His hair sheds off, and yet he speaks not so much in the nose as he did before.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.p: He has had the better chirurgeon, master Greenwit, is your wit so raw as to play no better a part then a sumner's?

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: I pray who plays a knack to know an honest man in this company?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gall.
sp.l: Dear husband, pardon me, I did dissemble,
Told thee I was his precontracted wife,
When letters came from him for thirty pound,
I had no shift but that.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: A very clean shift: but able to make me lousy, on.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.p: Husband, I plucked (When he had tempted me to think well of him) get feathers from thy wings, to make him fly more lofty.

sp.speaker: Maist. gall
sp.l: A'the top of you wife: on.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gal.
sp.l: He having wasted them, comes now for more,
Using me as a ruffian doth his whore,
Whose sin keeps him in breath: by heaven I vow,
Thy bed he never wronged, more than he does now.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: My bed? ha, ha, like enough, a shopboard will serve to have a cuckold's coat cut out upon: of that we'll talk hereafter: you're a villain ▪

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: Hear me but speak sir, you shall find me none.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Pray sir, be patient and hear him.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: I am muzzled for biting sir, use me how you will.

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: The first hour that your wife was in my eye,
Myself with other gentlemen sitting by,
(In your shop) tasting smoke, and speech being used,
That men who have fairest wives are most abused,
And hardly scaped the horn, your wife maintained
That only such spots in city dames were stained,
Justly, but by men's slanders: for her own part,
She vowed that you had so much of her heart;
No man by all his wit, by any wile,
Never so fine spun, should yourself be guile,
Of what in her was yours.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.p: Yet Pru 'tis well: play out your game at Irish sir: who wins?

sp.speaker: Mistress Open.
sp.l: The trial is when she comes to bearing:

sp.speaker: Lax.
sp.l: I scorned one woman, thus, should brave all men,
And (Which more vexed me) a she-citizen.
Therefore I laid siege to her, out she held,
Gave many a brave repulse, and me compelled
with shame to sound retreat to my hot lust,
Then seeing all base desires raked up in dust,
And that to tempt her modest ears, I swore
Ne'er to presume again: she said, her eye
Would ever give me welcome honestly,
And (Since I was a gentleman) if it run low,
She would my state relieve, not to o'erthrow
Your own and hers: did so; then seeing I wrought
Upon her meekness, me she set at naught,
And yet to try if I could turn that tide,
You see what stream I strove with, but sir I swear
By heaven, and by those hopes men lay up there,
I neither have, nor had a base intent
To wrong your bed, what's done, is merriment:
Your gold I pay back with this interest,
When I had most power to do't I wronged you least.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: If this no gullery be sir,

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: No, no, on my life,

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: Then sir I am beholden (Not to you wife)
But master Laxton to your want of doing ill,
Which it seems you have not gentlemen,
Tarry and dine here all.

sp.speaker: Maist. Open.
sp.l: Brother, we have a jest,
As good as yours to furnish out a feast.

sp.speaker: Maist. Gal.
sp.l: We'll crown our table with it: wife brag no more,
Of holding out: who most brags is most whore.
sp.stage: Enter Jack dapper, Moll, sir beautious Ganymed, and sir Thomas Long.

sp.speaker: Jack Dap.
sp.p: But prithee master captain Jack be plain and perspicuous with me; was it your Megge of Westminster's courage, that rescued me from the poultry puttocks indeed.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p:
The valour of my wit I ensure you sir fetched you off bravely, when you were i'the forlorn hope among those desperates, sir bewtious Ganymed here, and sir Thomas long heard that cuckoo (My man Trapdore) sing the note of your
ransom from captivity.

sp.speaker: Sir bewt.
sp.l: Uds so Moll, where's that Trapdore?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Hanged I think by this time, a justice in this town, (That speaks nothing but make a mittimus a way with him to Newgate) used that rogue like a firework to run upon a line betwixt him and me.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: How, how?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Marry to lay trains of villainy to blow up my life; I smelled the powder, spied what linstock gave fire to shoot against the poor captain of the Gallifoyst, and away slid I my man, like a shovel-board shilling, he struts up and down the suburbs I think: and eats up whores: feeds upon a bawd's garbage.

sp.speaker: T. Long.
sp.l: Sirrah Jack dapper.

sp.speaker: Jac, Dap.
sp.l: What sayest Tom long?

sp.speaker: T. Long.
sp.p: Thou hadst a sweet faced boy hail fellow with thee to your little gull: how is he spent?

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.p: Troth I whistled the poor little buzzard of a my fist, because when he waited upon me at the ordinaries, the gallants hit me i'the teeth still, and said I looked like a painted alderman's tomb, and the boy at my elbow like a death's head. Sirrah Jack, Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: What says my little dapper?

sp.speaker: Sir bewt.
sp.l: Come, come, walk and talk, walk and talk.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.l: Moll and I'll be i'the midst.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: These knights shall have squires places belike then: well dapper what say y ou?

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.p: Sirrah captain mad Mary, the gull my own father (Dapper) sir Davy) laid these London boot-halers the catch poles in ambush to set upon me.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Your father? away Jack.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.p: By the tassells of this handkercher 'tis true, and what was his warlike stratagem think you? he thought because a wicker cage tames a nightingale, a lousy prison could make an ass of me.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: A nasty plot.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.p:
I; as though a counter, which is a park, in which
all the wild beasts of the city run head by head could tame me.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Yonder comes my lord Noland.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Save you my lord.

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.p: Well met gentlemen all, good sir bewtious Ganymed, sir Thomas long?, and how does master dapper?

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.l: Thanks my lord.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: No tobacco my lord?

sp.speaker: L. Nol
sp.l: No faith Jack.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.p: My lord Noland will you go to Pimlico with us? we are making a boon voyage to that nappy land of spice-cakes

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.p: Here's such a merry ging, I could find in my heart to sail to the world's end with such company, come gentlemen let's on.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.l: Here's most amorous weather my lord.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Amorous weather.

sp.speaker: Jac. Dap.
sp.l: Is not amorous a good word?
sp.stage: Enter Trapdore like a poor soldier with a patch o'er one eye, and Teare-cat with him, all tatters.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Shall we set upon the infantry, these troops of foot? Zounds yonder comes Moll my whorish master and mistress, would I had her kidneys between my teeth.

sp.speaker: Tear-cat.
sp.l: I had rather have a cow heel.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Zounds I am so patched up, she cannot discover me: we'll on.

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.l: Alla corago then.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Good your honours, and worships, enlarge the ears of commiseration, and let the sound of a hoarse military organ-pipe, penetrate your pitiful bowels to extract out of them so many small drops of silver, as may give a hard straw-bed lodging to a couple of maimed soldiers.

sp.speaker: Jack Dap.
sp.l: Where are you maimed?

sp.speaker: T Cat.
sp.l: In both our nether limbs.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Come, come, dapper, let's give 'em something, 'las poor men, what money have you? by my troth I love a soldier with my soul.

sp.speaker: Sir bewt.
sp.l: Stay, stay, where have you served?

sp.speaker: T. Long.
sp.l: In any part of the low countries?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Not in the low countries, if it please your manhood, but in Hungary against the Turk at the siege of Belgrad.

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: Who served there with you sirrah?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Many Hungarians, Moldavians, Valachians, and Transylvanians, with some Sclavonians, and retiring home sir, the Venetian galleys took us prisoners, yet freed us, and suffered us to beg up and down the country.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.l: You have ambled all over Italy then.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: O sir, from Venice to Roma, Vecchio, Bononia, Romania, Bolonia, Modena, Piacenza, and Tuscana, with all her cities, as Pistoia, Valteria, Mountepulchena, Arrezzo, with the siennois, and divers others.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Mere rogues, put spurs to 'em once more.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.p: Thou lookest like a strange creature, a fat butterbox, yet speak'st English,
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.l: Ick mine here. Ick been den ruffling Tear-cat.
Den, brave soldade, ick been dorick all Dutchlant.
Gueresen: der shellum das mere ine beasa
Ine woert gaeb.
Ick slaag vin strokes ou tom cop.
Dastick den hundred touzun devil hall,
Frolic mive here.

sp.speaker: Sir bewt.
sp.l: Here, here, let's be rid of their jobbering,

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Not a cross sir bewtiout, you base rogues, I have taken measure of you, better than a tailor can, and I'll fit you, as you (Monster with one eye) have fitted me,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Your worship will not abuse a soldier.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Soldier? thou deservest to be hanged up by that tongue which dishonours so noble a profession, soldier you skeldering varlet? hold, stand, there should be a trap-door hereabouts .

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: The balls of these glasiers of mine (Mine eyes) shall be shot up and down in any hot piece of service for my invincible mistress.

sp.speaker: Jack Dap.
sp.p: I did not think there had been such knavery in black patches as now I see.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: O sir he hath been brought up in the I'll of dogs, and can both fawn like a spaniel, and bite like a mastiff, as he finds occasion.

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: What are you sirrah? A bird of this feather too.

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.l: A man beaten from the wars sir.

sp.speaker: T. Long.
sp.l: I think so, for you never stood to fight.

sp.speaker: Jac. Dap.
sp.l: What's thy name fellow soldier?

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.l: I am called by those that have seen my valour, tear-cat.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Tear-cat?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: A mere whiplack, and that is in the commonwealth of rogues, a slave, that can talk of sea-fight, name all your chief pirates, discover more countries to you, then either the Dutch, Spanish, French, or English ever found out, yet indeed all his service is by land, and that is to rob a fair, or some such venturous exploit; Tear-cat, foot sirrah I have your name now I remember me in my book of horners, horns for the thumb, you know how.

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.p: No indeed captain Moll (For I know you by sight) I am no such nipping christian, but a maunderer upon the pad I confess, and meeting with honest Trapdore here, whom you had cashiered from bearing arms, out at elbows under your colours, I instructed him in the rudiments of roguery, and by my map made him sail over any country you can name, so that now he can maunder better than myself.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.l: So then Trapdore thou art turned soldier now.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Alas sir, now there's no wars, 'tis the safest course of life I could take.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p:
I hope than you can cant, for by your cudgels, you
sirrah are an upright man.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: As any walks the high way I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: And Tear-cat what are you? A wild rogue, an angler, or a ruffler?

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.p: Brother to this upright man, flesh and blood, ruffling Tear-cat is my name, and a ruffler is my style, my title, my profession.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Sirrah where's your doxy, halt not with me.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Doxy Moll, what's that?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: His wench.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My doxy I have by the Salomon a doxy, that carries a kitchen mort in her slat at her back, besides my dell and my dainty wild deal, with all whom I'll tumble this next darkmans in the strummel, and drink been baufe, and eat a fat gruntling cheat, a cackling cheat, and a quacking cheat.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.l: Here's old cheating.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My doxy stays for me in a bousing ken, brave captain.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: He says his wench stays for him in an alehouse: you are no pure rogues.

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.p: Pure rogues? no, we scorn to be pure rogues, but if you come to our lib ken, or our stalling ken, you shall find neither him nor me, a choir cuffin.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: So sir, no churl of you.

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.l: No, but a been cave, a brave cave, a gentry cuffin.

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: Call you this canting?

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.p: Zounds, I'll give a schoolmaster half a crown a week, and teach me this pedlars French.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Do but stroll sir, half a harvest with us sir, and you shall gabble your bellyful.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Come you rogue cant with me.

sp.speaker: T. Long.
sp.p: Well said Moll, cant with her sirrah, and you shall have money, else not a penny.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I'll have a bout if she please.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Come on sirrah.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Ben mort, shall you and I heave a booth, mill a ken or nip a bung, and then we'll couch a hogshead under the ruffemans,
and there you shall wap with me, and I'll niggle with you.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Out you damned impudent rascal.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Cut benar whiddes, and hold your fambles and your stamps.

sp.speaker: L Nol.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Moll, why art thou angry? what was his gibberish?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Marry this my lord says he; ben mort (Good wench) shall you and I heave a booth, mill a ken, or nip a bung? shall you and I rob a house, or cut a purse?

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Very good. (Man's:

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: And then we'll couch a hogshead under the ruff -
And then we'll lie under a hedge.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: That was my desire captain, as 'tis fit a soldier should lie.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: And there you shall wap with me, and I'll niggle with you, and that's all.

sp.speaker: Sir bewt.
sp.l: Nay, nay Moll what's that wap?

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.p: Nay teach me what niggling is, I'd fain be niggling.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Wapping and niggling is all one, the rogue my man can tell you.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: 'Tis fadoodling: if it please you.

sp.speaker: Sir bewt.
sp.l: This is excellent, one fit more good Moll,

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Come you rogue sing with me.
A gage of been rom-bouse
In a bousing ken of rom-vile.

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.l: Is benar then a caster,
Peck, pennam, lay or popler,
Which we mill in deuse a vile.
O I would lib all the lightmans.
O I would lib all the darkemans,
By the sollamon under the ruffemans.
By the sollamon in the hartmans.

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.l: And scour the choir cramp ring,
And couch till a pallyard docked my dell,
So my bouzy nab might skew roam bouse well
avast to the pad, let us bing,
Avast to the pad, let us bing.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Fine knaves i'faith.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.p: The grating of ten new cartwheels, and the gruntling of five hundred hogs coming from Rumford market, cannot make a worse noise than this canting language does in my ears; pray my lord Noland, let's give these soldiers their pay.

sp.speaker: Sir bewt.
sp.l: Agreed, and let them march.

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: Here Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Now I see that you are staled to the rogue, and are not ashamed of your professions, look you: my lord Noland here and these gentlemen, bestows upon you two, two boards and a half, that's two shillings six pence.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Thanks to your lordship.

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.l: Thanks heroical captain.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: We shall cut been whiddes of your masters and mistress-ship, wheresoever we come.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: You'll maintain sirrah the old justice's plot to his face.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Else trine me on the cheats: hang me.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Be sure you meet me there.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Without any more maundering I'll do't, follow brave tear-cat.
sp.stage: Exeunt they two manet the rest.

sp.speaker: T. Cat.
sp.l: I prae, sequor, let us go mouse.

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: Moll what was in that canting song? (Only milk

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Troth my lord, only a praise of good drink, the
Which these wild beasts love to suck, and thus it was:
A rich cup of wine, o it is juice divine,
More wholesome for the head,: hen meat, drink, or bread,
To fill my drunken pate, with that, I'd sit up late,
By the heels would I lie, under a lousy hedge die,
Let a slave have a pull at my whore, so I be full
Of that precious liquor; and a parcel of such stuff my lord
Not worth the opening.
sp.stage: Enter a cutpurse very gallant, with four or five men after him, one with a wand.

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: What gallant comes yonder?

sp.speaker: T. Long.
sp.l: Mass I think I know him, 'tis one of Cumberland.

sp.speaker: 1 cut
sp.p: Shall we venture to shuffle in amongst yond heap of gallants, and strike?

sp.speaker: 2 cut
sp.p: 'Tis a question whether there be any silver shells amongst them, for all their satin outsides.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Let's try?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Pox on him, a gallant? shadow me, I know him: 'tis one that cumbers the land indeed; if he swim near to the shore of any of your pockets, look to your purses.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: This brave fellow is no better than a foist.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Foist, what's that?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: A diver with two fingers, a pickpocket; all his train study the figging law, that's to say; cutting of purses and foisting; one of them is a nip, I took him once i'the twopenny gallery at the fortune; then there's a cloyer, or snap, that dogs any new brother in that trade, and snaps will have half in any booty; he with the wand is both a stale, whose office is, to face a man i'the streets, whilst shells are drawn by another, and then with his black conjuring rod in his hand, he by the nimbleness of his eye and juggling stick, will in cheaping a piece of plate at a goldsmith's stall, make four or five rings mount from the top of his caduceus, and as if it were at leapfrog, they skip into his hand presently.

sp.speaker: 2. cut
sp.l: Zounds we are smoked.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: 2. cut
sp.p: We are boiled, pox on her; see Moll the roaring drab.

sp.speaker: 1. cut
sp.l: All the diseases of sixteen hospitals boil her: away.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Bless you sir.

sp.speaker: 1. cut
sp.l: And you good sir.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Dost not ken me man?

sp.speaker: 1. cut
sp.l: No trust me sir.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Heart, there's a knight to whom I'm bound for many favours, lost his purse at the last new play i'the swan, seven angels in't, make it good you're best; do you see? no more.

sp.speaker: 1. cut
sp.p: A synagogue shall be called mistress Mary, disgrace me not; pacus palabros, I will conjure for you, farewell:

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Did not I tell you my lord?

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.p: I wonder how thou cam'st to the knowledge of these nasty villains.

sp.speaker: T. Long.
sp.p: And why do the foul mouths of the world call thee Moll cutpurse? A name, methinks , damned and odious.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Dare any step forth to my face and say,
I have ta'en thee doing so Moll? I must confess,
In younger days, when I was apt to stray,
I have sat amongst such adders; seen their stings,
As any here might, and in full playhouses
Watched their quick-diving hands, to bring to shame
Such rogues, and in that stream met an ill name:
When next my lord you spy any one of those,
So he be in his art a scholar, question him,
Tempt him with gold to open the large book
Of his close villainies: and you yourself shall cant
Better than poor Moll can, and know more laws
Of cheaters, lifters, nips, foists, puggards, curbers,
Withal the devil's black guard, than it is fit
Should be discovered to a noble wit.
I know they have their orders, offices,
Circuits and circles, unto which they are bound,
To raise their own damnation in.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.l: How dost thou know it?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: As you do, I show it you, they to me show it.
Suppose my lord you were in Venice.

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: If some Italian pander there would tell
All the close tricks of courtesans; would not you
Harken to such a fellow?

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: And here,
being come from Venice, to a friend most dear
That were to travel thither, you would proclaim
Your knowledge in those villainies, to save
Your friend from their quick danger: must you have
A black ill name, because ill things you know,
Good troth my lord, I am made Moll cut purse so.
How many are whores, in small ruffs and still looks?
How many chaste, whose names fill slanders books?
Were all men cuckolds, whom gallants in their scorns
Call so, we should not walk for goring horns,
Perhaps for my mad going some reprove me,
I please myself, and care not else who loves me.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: A brave mind Moll i'faith.

sp.speaker: T. long.
sp.l: Come my lord, shall's to the ordinary?

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: Ay, 'tis noon sure. (Or to the world:

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Good my lord, let not my name condemn me to you
A fencer I hope may be called a coward, is he so for that?
If all that have ill names in London, were to be whipped, (There
And to pay but twelve pence a piece to the beadle, I would ra -
Have his office, than a constable's.

sp.speaker: Jack. Dap.
sp.p: So would I captain Moll: 'twere a sweet tickling office i'faith.
sp.stage: Enter sir Alexander Wengraue, goshawk and Greenwit, and others.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: My son marry a thief, that impudent girl,
Whom all the world stick their worst eyes upon?

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.l: How will your care prevent it?

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible.
They marry close, they're gone, but none knows whither.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O gentlemen, when has a father's heartstrings
Held out so long from breaking: now what news sir?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: They were met upo'the water an hour since, sir,
Putting in towards the sluice.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The sluice? come gentlemen,
'tis Lambeth works against us.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: And that Lambeth, joins more mad matches, than your six wet towns, twixt that and Windsor-bridge, where fares lie soaking.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Delay no time sweet gentlemen: to black friars,
We'll take a pair of oars and make after 'em.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Your son, and that bold masculine ramp
My mistress, are landed now at tower.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Hoyda, at tower?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I heard it now reported.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Which way gentlemen shall I bestow my care?
I'm drawn in pieces betwixt deceit and shame.

sp.speaker: Fitz-alla.
sp.l: Sir Alexander.
You're well met, and most rightly served,
My daughter was a scorn to you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Say not so fir.

sp.speaker: Fitz-all.
sp.l: A very abject, she poor gentlewoman,
Your house had been dishonoured. Give you joy sir,
Of your son's gascoin-bride, you'll be a grandfather shortly
To a fine crew of roaring sons and daughters,
'Twill help to stock the suburbs passing well sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O play not with the miseries of my heart,
Wounds should be dressed and healed, not vexed, or left
Wide open, to the anguish of the patient,
And scornful air let in: rather let pity
And advise charitably help to refresh 'em.

sp.speaker: Fitz-all.
sp.l: Who'd place his charity so unworthily.
Like one that gives alms to a cursing beggar,
Had I but found one spark of goodness in you
Towards my deserving child, which then grew fond
Of your son's virtues, I had cased you now.
But I perceive both fire of youth and goodness,
Are raked up in the ashes of your age,
Else no such shame should have come near your house,
Nor such ignoble sorrow touch your heart,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: If not for worth, for pities sake assist me.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.l: You urge a thing passed sense, how can he help you?
All his assistance is as frail as ours,
Full as uncertain, where's the place that holds 'em?
One brings us water-news; then comes another
With a full charged mouth, like a culverin's voice,
And he reports the tower; whose sounds are truest?

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: In vain you flatter him sir Alexander.

sp.speaker: Fitz-all.
sp.l: I flatter him, gentlemen you wrong me grossly.

sp.speaker: Greene,
sp.l: He does it well i'faith.

sp.speaker: Fitz-all.
sp.l: Both news are false,
Of tower or water: they took no such way yet. (Plunges?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O strange: hear you this gentlemen, yet more

sp.speaker: Fiz-alla.
sp.p: They're nearer than you think for yet more close, then if they were further off.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: How am I lost in these distractions?

sp.speaker: Fitz-alla.
sp.l: For your speeches gentlemen,
In taxing me for rashness; fore you all,
I will engage my state to half his wealth,
Nay to his son's revenues, which are less,
And yet nothing at all, till they come from him;
That I could (If my will stuck to my power),
Prevent this marriage yet, nay banish her
For ever from his thoughts, much more his arms.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Slack not this goodness, though you heap upon me
Mountains of malice and revenge hereafter:
I'd willingly resign up half my state to him,
So he would marry the meanest drudge I hire.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.l: He talks impossibilities, and you believe 'em.

sp.speaker: Fitz-alla.
sp.l: I talk no more, than I know how to finish,
My fortunes else are his that dares stake with me,
The poor young gentleman I love and pity:
And to keep shame from him, (Because the spring
Of his affection was my daughter's first,
Till his frown blasted all,) do but estate him
In those possessions, which your love and care
Once pointed out for him, that he may have room,
to entertain fortunes of noble birth,
Where now his desperate wants casts him upon her:
And if I do not for his own sake chiefly,
Rid him of this disease, that now grows on him,
I'll forfeit my whole state, before these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.l: Troth but you shall not undertake such matches,
We'll persuade so much with you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Here's my ring,
He will believe this token: fore these gentlemen,
I will confirm it fully: all those lands,
My first love lotted him, he shall straight possess
In that refusal.

sp.speaker: Fitz-all.
sp.l: If I change it not, change me into a beggar.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.l: Are you mad sir?

sp.speaker: Fitz-all.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Will you undo yourself by doing,
And show a prodigal trick in your old days?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: 'Tis a match gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fitz-all.
sp.l: Ay, ay, sir I.
I ask no favour; trust to you for none,
My hope rests in the goodness of your son.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.l: He holds it up well yet.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Of an old knight i'faith.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Cursed be the time, I laid his first love barren,
Wilfully barren, that before this hour
Had sprung forth fruits, of comfort and of honour;
He loved a virtuous gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Life, here's Moll.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.l: Jack.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: How dost thou Jack?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: How dost thou gallant?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Impudence, where's my son?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Weakensse, go look him.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Is this your wedding gown?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: The man talks monthly:
Hot broth and a dark chamber for the knight,
I see he'll be stark mad at our next meeting.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Why sir, take comfort now, there's no such matter,
no priest will marry her, sir, for a woman,
Whiles that shape's on, and it was never known,
Two men were married and conjoined in one:
Your son hath made some shift to love another.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Whate'er 'She be, she has my blessing with her,
May they be rich, and fruitful, and receive
Like comfort to their issue, as I take in them,
Has pleased me now, marrying not this,
Through a whole world he could not choose amiss.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.l: Glad you're so penitent, for your former sin sir.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: Say he should take a wench with her smock-dowry,
No portion with her, but her lips and arms?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Why? who thrive better sir? they have most blessing,
Though other have more wealth, and least repent,
Many that want most, know the most content.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.l: Say he should marry a kind youthful sinner.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Age will quench that, any offence but theft and drunkenness
Nothing but death can wipe away. ,
There sins are green, even when there heads are grey,
Nay I despair not now, my heart's cheered gentlemen,
No face can come unfortunately to me,
Now sir, your news?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Your son with his fair bride is near at hand,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Fair may their fortunes be.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.l: Now you're resolved sir, it was never she,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I find it in the music of my heart,
sp.stage: Enter Mol masked, in Sebastian's hand, and Fitz-allard.
sp.l: See where they come.

sp.speaker: Gosh.
sp.l: A proper lusty presence sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Now has he pleased me right, I always counselled him
To choose a goodly personable creature,
Just of her pitch was my first wife his mother.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Before I dare discover my offence, I kneel for pardon.

sp.speaker: Alex;
sp.l: My heart gave it thee, before thy tongue could ask it,
Rise, thou hast raised my joy to greater height.
Then to that seat where grief dejected it,
Both welcome to my love, and care for ever,
Hide not my happiness too long, all's pardoned,
Here are our friends, salute her, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Heart, who this Moll?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O my reviving shame, is't I must live,
To be struck blind, be it the work of sorrow,
Before age take't in hand.

sp.speaker: Fitz-all.
sp.l: Darkness and death.
Have you deceived me thus? did I engage
My whole estate for this.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: You asked no favour,
And you shall find as little, since my comforts,
Play false with me, I'll be as cruel to thee
As grief to father's hearts.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Why what's the matter with you?
Less too much joy, should make your age forgetful,
Are you too well, too happy?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: With a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Methinks you should be proud of such a daughter,
As good a man, as your son.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O monstrous impudence.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: You had no note before, an unmarked knight,
Now all the town will take regard on you,
And all your enemies fear you for my sake,
You may pass where you list, through crowds most thick,
And come of bravely with your purse unpicked,
You do not know the benefits I bring with me,
No cheat dares work upon you, with thumb or knife,
While you've a roaring girl to your son's wife.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: A devil rampant.

sp.speaker: Fitz-alla.
sp.l: Have you so much charity?
Yet to release me of my last rash bargain,
And I'll give in your pledge.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No sir, I stand to't, I'll work upon advantage,
As all mischiefs do upon me.

sp.speaker: Aitz-all.
sp.l: Content, bear witness all then
his are the lands, and so contention ends.
Here comes your son's bride, twixt two noble friends.
sp.stage: Enter the lord Noland, and sir bewtious Ganymed, with Marry Fitz-allard between them, the citizens and their wives with them.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Now are you gulled as you would be, thank me for't,
I'd a fore-finger in't.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Forgive me father,
Though there before your eyes my sorrow feigned,
This still was she, for whom true love complained.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Blessings eternal, and the joys of angels,
Begin your peace here, to be signed in heaven,
How short my sleep of sorrow seems now to me,
To this eternity of boundless comforts,
That finds no want but utterance, and expression.
My lord your office here appears so honourably:
So full of ancient goodness, grace, and worthiness,
I never took more joy in sight of man,
Then in your comfortable presence now.

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: Nor I more delight in doing grace to virtue,
Then in this worthy gentlewoman, your son's bride,
Noble Fitz-allard's daughter, to whose honour
And modest fame, I am a servant vowed,
So is this knight.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Your loves make my joys proud,
Bring forth those deeds of land, my care laid ready,
And which, old knight, thy nobleness may challenge,
Joined with thy daughter's virtues, whom I prize now,
As dear as that flesh, I call mine own.
Forgive me worthy gentlewoman, 'twas my blindness
When I rejected thee, I saw thee not,
Sorrow and wilful rashness grew like films
Over the eyes of judgement, now so clear
I see the brightness of thy worth appear.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Duty and love may I deserve in those,
and all my wishes have a perfect close,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: That tongue can never err, the sound's so sweet,
Here honest son, receive into thy hands,
The keys of wealth, possession of those lands,
Which my first care provided, they're thine own,
Heaven give thee a blessing with 'em, the best joys,
That can in worldly shapes to man betide,
Are fertile lands, and a fair fruitful bride,
Of which I hope thou'rt sped.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I hope so too sir.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Father and son, I ha'done you simple service here,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: For which thou shalt not part Moll unrequited.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Thou art a mad girl, and yet I cannot now condemn thee.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Condemn me? troth and you should sir,
I'd make you seek out one to hang in my room,
I'd give you the slip at gallows, and cozen the people.
Herded you this jest my lord?

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: What is it Jack?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: He was in fear his son would marry me,
But never dreamt that I would ne'er agree.

sp.speaker: L. Nol.
sp.l: Why? thou hadst a suitor once Jack, when wilt marry?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Who I my lord, I'll tell you when i'faith,
When you shall hear,
Gallants void from sergeant's fear,
Honesty and truth unslandered,
Woman maned, but never pandered,
